sen.j: 徳川 家康（とくがわ いえやす）は、日本の武将・江戸幕府の初代征夷大将軍。

sen.j: 応仁の乱以降100年以上続いた戦乱に終止符を打ち、織田信長、豊臣秀吉により統一された天下を更に磐石のものとし、264年間続いた江戸幕府を開府し、その礎を築いた。
sen.e: The war state of the nation that continued for more than 100 years after Onin War was ended by Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, and succeeding them, Ieyasu made the national state more stable, and started the Edo bakufu and made its base solidified so that the bakufu could continue for 264 years.

sen.e: He was born on December 26 (in the old calendar) (around 4 AM), 1542, in the Okazaki castle as the heir son of Hirotada MATSUDAIRA, the eighth head of the Matsudaira main family.

sen.j: 6歳の時、松平広忠は織田氏に対抗するため、駿河国の今川氏に臣従し、竹千代は今川氏の人質として駿河国・駿府へ送られることとなった。
sen.e: To confront the Oda clan, Hirotada MATSUDAIRA became a vassal of the Imagawa clan in Suruga when he was six years old, and it was decided that Takechiyo should be sent to Sunpu in Suruga Province to be placed in the custody of the Imagawa family as a hostage.

sen.j: しかし、駿府への護送の途中に立ち寄った田原城 (三河国)で義母の父・戸田康光の裏切りにより、尾張国の織田氏へ送られた。
sen.e: However, when he called at Tahara-jo Castle (in Mikawa Province) en route to be sent to Sunpu, Yasumitsu TODA (the father of his mother-in-law) acted the treachery of sending him to the Oda family in Owari Province.

sen.j: しかし松平広忠は今川氏への臣従を貫いたため、竹千代は見捨てられた形となり、そのまま人質として尾張国に留め置かれた。
sen.e: However, Hirotada MATSUDAIRA continued being a vassal of the Imagawa clan, and therefore, being in the state of having been abandoned, Takechiyo was left staying in Owari Province.

sen.j: 今川義元は織田信秀の庶長子・織田信広（前年の1549年、安祥城を 太原雪斎に城を攻められ生け捕りにされている）との人質交換によって竹千代を取り戻す。
sen.e: Yoshimoto IMAGAWA took back Takechiyo by exchanging hostages between him and Nobuhiro ODA, the eldest son born out of wedlock of Nobuhide ODA, (who was captured alive when Ansho-jo Castle was attacked in 1549 by Sessai TAIGEN).

sen.j: しかし竹千代は駿府（『東照宮御実紀』では少将宮町、武徳編年集成』では宮カ崎とされている）に移され、岡崎城は今川氏より派遣された城代により支配された。

sen.j: 墓参りのためと称し岡崎城に帰参した際には、本丸は今川氏の城代が置かれていたため本丸には入れず、二の丸に入った。
sen.e: When visiting Okazaki Castle saying that he came to pay a visit to his ancestors' graves, he could not enter the honmaru (the main compound of the castle), because the jodai officer occupied there, and entered the ninomaru (the second compound of the castle).

sen.e: On this occasion, he heard from Tadayoshi TORII that the gokenin of the Matsudaira family there were used as a spearhead, or as virtually a sacrifice group.

sen.e: It is said that he moved to tears when Tadayoshi TORII showed him the arms, military provisions and money that Tadayoshi had kept secret from the Imagawa clan.

sen.e: Elder gokenin are said to have wondered that he quite resembled Kiyoyasu MATSUDAIRA, his grandfather.

sen.j: 名は後に祖父・松平清康の偏諱をもらって松平蔵人佐元康と改めている。

sen.e: In 1558, he attacked Suzuki Hyuga no kami, the lord of Terabe Castle, who had gone over to the Oda clan side, together with Shigeyosi MATSUDAIRA and others.

sen.j: 従来、松平広忠の嫡男である竹千代を人質に取った処遇は、今川氏による松平氏に対する過酷な処遇であるというのが通説であった。
sen.e: It was a general theory that placing Takechiyo, the heir son of Hirotada MATSUDAIRA, in the custody as a postage was too harsh a treatment of the Matsudaira family by the Imagawa family.

sen.j: しかし近年、むしろ今川義元の好意（もちろん義元の側の思惑もあるが）によるものだという説が唱えられている。
sen.e: However, the theory that the treatment would have been a favor by Yoshimoto IMAGAWA (although there might have been an intention on the Yoshimoto side) has recently been proposed.

sen.j: 人質というよりも「政務見習い」として預けられたという説もある。
sen.e: There is a theory that he was entrusted to the Imagawa family not as a hostage but for "learning government affairs."

sen.e: Actually, there exists the theory that he was educated especially by Sessai TAIGEN (there is a theory that this was not a fact).

sen.j: 姪である築山殿を嫁がせているのも、政略的な一面がある一方、一門として迎え入れる厚遇という見方もある。
sen.e: Having made him marry Yoshimoto's niece had a political aspect, but on the other hand, there is a viewpoint that it was a kind treatment of welcoming him into the Imagawa clan.

sen.j: ただし松平氏の家臣にとっては上述の通り主君を人質に取られて走狗として酷使された印象を与え、竹千代が今川義元の家臣（孕石元泰）から個人的な虐めを受けるなど、忍従の日々であった。
sen.e: However, the situation gave the retainers of the Matsudaira family the impression that, as described above, they had their lord taken as a hostage and were worked hard as tools of the Imagawa clan, and Takechiyo himself lived a life of submission, for example, by being ill-treated personally by a retainer of Yoshimoto IMAGAWA (Motoyasu HARAMIISHI).

sen.e: From these situations, the viewpoint of the Matsudaira family was handed down to later generations, becoming to constitute a general theory.

tit.j: 清洲同盟から三河国・遠江国平定
tit.e: The era from making the Kiyosu alliance to suppressing Mikawa Province and Totomi Province
The era from making the Kiyosu alliance to suppressing Mikawa Province and Totomi Province

sen.j: 永禄3年（1560年）5月、桶狭間の戦いで今川義元が織田信長に討たれた際、今川軍本隊とは別働で、前線の尾張国・大高城を攻略中であった元康は、大高城から撤退。
sen.e: When Yoshimoto IMAGAWA was killed by Nobunaga ODA in May (in the old calendar) of 1560 in the Battle of Okehazama, Motoyasu, who had been detached from the main Imagawa troop and was attacking Odaka Castle in Owari Province in the front line, retreated from Odaka Castle.

When Yoshimoto IMAGAWA was killed by Nobunaga ODA in May (in the old calendar) of 1560 in the Battle of Okehazama, Motoyasu, who had been detached from the main Imagawa troop and was attacking Odaka Castle in Owari Province in the front line, retreated from Odaka Castle.

When Yoshimoto IMAGAWA was killed by Nobunaga ODA in May (in the old calendar) of 1560 in the Battle of Okehazama, Motoyasu, who had been detached from the main Imagawa troop and was attacking Odaka-jo Castle in Owari Province in the front line, retreated from Odaka-jo Castle.

sen.j: 今川軍が放棄した岡崎城に入ると、祖父・松平清康の代で確立した三河国の支配権回復を志し、今川氏から独立する。
sen.e: After entering Okazaki Castle abandoned by the Imagawa troop, he became independent of the Imagawa family, intending to restore the right of controlling Mikawa Province that Kiyoyasu MATSUDAIRA, his grandfather, had once established.

After entering Okazaki-jo Castle abandoned by the Imagawa troops, he became independent of the Imagawa clan, intending to restore the right of controlling Mikawa Province that Kiyoyasu MATSUDAIRA, his grandfather, had once established.

sen.j: 藤波畷の戦いなどに勝利して、西三河の諸城を攻略した。
sen.e: He conquered castles in the western Mikawa area, for example, by winning the Battle of Fujinami-nawate.
He conquered castles in the western Mikawa area, for example, by winning the Battle of Fujinami-nawate.
He conquered castles in the western Mikawa area, for example, by winning the Battle of Fujinami-nawate.

sen.j: 永禄5年（1562年）には、義元の後を継いだ今川氏真と断交して信長と同盟を結んだ（清洲同盟）。
sen.e: In 1562, he severed relations with Ujizane IMAGAWA who had succeeded Yoshimoto, and made an alliance with Nobunaga (called the Kiyosu alliance).
In 1562, he severed relations with Ujizane IMAGAWA who had succeeded Yoshimoto, and made an alliance with Nobunaga (called the Kiyosu alliance).

sen.j: 翌年には義元からの偏諱である「元」の字を返上して元康から家康と名を改めた。
sen.e: In the next year, he changed his name to Ieyasu (家康) from Motoyasu (元康), returning the character of 元 (moto) that was included in name of 義元 ((修正候補なし)) and was allowed to use in his name.

sen.cmt: (修正候補なし)削除しました。人名修正補足しました。

sen.j: 西三河を平定しかけた頃、三河一向一揆が勃発するも苦心の末にこれを鎮圧した。
sen.e: When he almost conquered all of the western Mikawa area, Mikawa Ikko Ikki (an uprising of Ikko sect followers in Mikawa Province) erupted, but suppressed it after strenuous efforts.

sen.j: こうして岡崎市周辺の不安要素を取り払うと、対今川氏の戦略を推し進めた。
sen.e: Having removed anxious factors around Okazaki City in this way, he promoted strategies against the Imagawa clan.
Having removed anxious factors around Okazaki City in this way, he promoted strategies against the Imagawa clan.

sen.j: 東三河の戸田氏や西郷氏といった土豪を抱き込みながらも、軍勢を東へ進めて鵜殿氏のような敵対勢力を排除していった。
sen.e: While taking such powerful local clans as the Toda clan and the Saigo clan into his side, he moved his troops towards the east, eliminating enemy forces, such as the Udono clan.
While taking such powerful local clans as the Toda clan and the Saigo clan onto his side, he moved his troops towards the east, eliminating enemy forces, such as the Udono clan.
While taking such powerful local clans as the Toda clan and the Saigo clan in the eastern Mikawa onto his side, he moved his troops towards the east, eliminating enemy forces, such as the Udono clan.

sen.j: 三河国への対応に遅れる今川氏との間で、宝飯郡を主戦場とした攻防戦を繰り広げた後、永禄9年（1566年）までには東三河・奥三河（三河国北部）を平定し、三河国を統一した。
sen.e: With Hoi County as the main battle field, he fought with the Imagawa clan that delayed in taking actions for Mikawa Province, and then by 1566, he conquered the eastern Mikawa area and the Oku-Mikawa area (the northern part of Mikawa Province), unifying Mikawa Province.

sen.j: この年、朝廷から従五位、三河守の叙任を受け、徳川氏に改姓した。
sen.e: In this year, he was awarded Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank) and the Mikawa no kami post, and changed his family name to Tokugawa.

sen.j: この改姓に伴い、新田氏系統の清和源氏であることも公認させた。
sen.e: Corresponding to this change of his name, he made it acknowledged publicly that he was in the lineage of the Nitta clan and therefore, a descendant of Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan originated from Emperor Seiwa).

Corresponding to this change of his name, he made it known publicly that he was in the lineage of the Nitta clan and therefore, a descendant of Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan originated from Emperor Seiwa).

sen.j: 永禄11年（1568年）には氏真を駿府から追放した武田信玄と手を結んだ。
sen.e: In 1568, he tied up with Shingen TAKEDA who drove Ujizane out of Sunpu.
In 1568, he tied up with Shingen TAKEDA who drove Ujizane out of Sunpu.

sen.j: 同年末からは、今川領であった遠江国に侵攻し、浜松城を攻め落とした。
sen.e: From towards the end of the same year, he invaded into Totomi Province that was a territory of the Imagawa clan, and attacked Hamamatsu Castle and made it surrendered

From towards the end of the same year, he invaded into Totomi Province which was a territory of the Imagawa clan, and attacked Hamamatsu-jo Castle and made it surrender.

sen.j: 遠江国で越年したまま軍を退かずに、駿府から逃れた氏真を匿う掛川城を攻囲。
sen.e: Making his troops stay in Totomi Province in the year end and new year period without retreating, he besieged Kakegawa Castle where Ujizane, having fled from Sunpu, was sheltered.
Making his troops stay in Totomi Province in the year end and new year period without retreating, he besieged Kakegawa Castle where Ujizane, having fled from Sunpu, was sheltered.
Making his troops stay in Totomi Province in the year end and new year period without retreating, he besieged Kakegawa-jo Castle where Ujizane, having fled from Sunpu, was sheltered.

sen.j: 籠城戦の末に開城勧告を呼びかけて氏真を降し、遠江国を支配下においた。
sen.e: After continuing besieging the castle, he made Ujizane surrender by recommending the surrender of the castle, placing Totomi Province under his control..

sen.j: 永禄11年（1568年）、信長が室町幕府13代将軍・足利義輝の弟・足利義昭を奉じて上洛の途につくと、家康も信長へ援軍を派遣した。
sen.e: When Nobunaga was en route to Kyoto in 1568, supporting Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA, the younger brother of Yoshiteru ASHIKAGA, the 13th shogun of the Muromachi bakufu, Ieyasu sent his troop to help Nobunaga.

sen.j: 後年、足利義昭は天下の実権をめぐり信長との間に対立を深め、信長包囲網を形成した際、家康にも副将軍への就任を要請し協力を求めた。
sen.e: In later years, when deeply confronting Nobunaga over the real power to govern the nation and having formed an anti-Nobunaga network, Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA also asked for Ieyasu's cooperation through requesting him to assume the deputy shogun post.

sen.j: しかし家康はこれを黙殺し、朝倉義景・浅井長政の連合軍との姉川の戦いに参戦し、信長を助けた。
sen.e: However, Ieyasu ignored it, and to help Nobunaga, participated in the Battle of Anegawa against the allied forces of Yoshikage ASAKURA and Nagamasa ASAI.

sen.j: 元亀元年（1570年）、岡崎から遠江国の曳馬町に移るとここを浜松と改名し、浜松城を築きこれを本城とした。
sen.e: In 1570, he moved from Okazaki to Hikimacho in Totomi Province, changed the name of the place to Hamamatsu, and built Hamamatsu Castle as his main castle.

sen.j: 今川領分割に際して、大井川を境に東の駿河国を武田領、西の遠江国を徳川領とする協定を結んで、武田信玄とは友好関係を築いていた。
sen.e: In dividing the Imagawa territory, he and the Takeda clan concluded an agreement that Suruga Province in the east of the Oi-gawa River should be belonged to the Takeda clan and Totomi Province in the west to the Tokugawa clan, establishing a friendly relationship.

sen.j: しかし永禄11年（1569年）、信玄からは一方的に協定を破棄された上、信濃国から秋山信友に遠江国への侵攻を受けてしまう。
sen.e: However, in 1569, the agreement was nullified by Shingen unilaterally, and in addition, his Totomi province was invaded by Nobutomo AKIYAMA from Shinano Province.

sen.j: 徳川軍は北条氏康の協力を得て武田軍を退けたが、これを機に信玄と家康は敵対関係となった。
sen.e: The Tokugawa's troop drove back the Takeda's troop by getting cooperation from Ujiyasu HOJO, but after this, relations between Shingen and Ieyasu became hostile.

sen.j: 元亀3年（1572年）10月、信玄はついに上洛を開始し、徳川領である遠江国、三河国に侵攻してきた。
sen.e: In October (in the old calendar) of 1572, Shingen at last started going to Kyoto, and invaded Totomi Province and Mikawa Province, both of which were Tokugawa 's territories.

sen.j: これに対して家康は盟友・織田信長に援軍を要請した。
sen.e: For this, Ieyasu asked Nobunaga ODA, his sworn ally, for sending Oda's troop.

sen.j: しかしながら、織田軍も当時は朝倉義景、浅井長政、石山本願寺と抗争状態にあり、さらには美濃国・岩村城までを武田軍に攻撃されていた。
sen.e: However, the Oda's troop was fighting with Yoshikage ASAKURA, with Nagamasa AsAI, and with Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple, and in addition, was being attacked by Takeda's troop in the area up to Iwamura-jo Castle in Mino Province.

sen.j: そのため、援軍を送ることができず、徳川軍は単独で武田軍と戦うこととなる。
sen.e: Therefore, Nobunaga could not send his troop to help Ieyasu, and Tokugawa's troop had to fight with Takeda's troop independently.

sen.j: 遠江国に侵攻してきた武田軍本隊と戦うため、天竜川を渡って見附宿にまで進出。
sen.e: To fight with the main body of the Takeda's troop that had invaded into Totomi Province, Ieyasu's troop crossed the Tenryu-gawa River, advancing to Mitsukejuku.

sen.j: 二俣城を取られることを避けたい家康が、ひとまず武田軍の動向を探るために威力偵察に出たところを武田軍と遭遇し、一言坂で敗走する（一言坂の戦い）。
sen.e: To prevent Futamata-jo Castle from being taken by the Takeda side, Ieyasu conducted reconnaissance in force to know the movements of the Takeda's troop, but encountered Takeda's troop and was defeated at Hitokotozaka (the Battle of Hitokotozaka).

To prevent Futamata-jo Castle from being taken by the Takeda side, Ieyasu conducted reconnaissance in force to know the movements of Takeda's troops, but encountered Takeda's troops and was defeated at Hitokotozaka (the Battle of Hitokotozaka).

sen.j: 遠江国方面の武田軍本隊と同時に武田軍別働隊が侵攻する三河国方面への防備を充分に固められないばかりか、この戦いを機に徳川軍の劣勢は確定してしまう。
sen.e: In the Mikawa Province area where another Takeda's troop separate from the main troop had begun to invade, he could not make defensive preparations adequately either, and consequently, his inferior position was fixed after this battle.

In the Mikawa Province area where more of Takeda's troops separate from the main army had begun to invade, he could not make defensive preparations adequately either, and consequently, his inferior position was fixed after this battle.

sen.j: そして12月、浜松の北方を固める遠江国の要衝であった二俣城が落城した（二俣城の戦い）。
sen.e: Then in December (in the old calendar), Futamata-jo Castle, the strategic place for defending the northern area of Hamamatsu in Totomi Province, was surrendered (the Battle of Futamata-jo Castle).
Then in December (in the old calendar), Futamata-jo Castle, the strategic place for defending the northern area of Hamamatsu in Totomi Province, was surrendered (the Battle of Futamata-jo Castle).

sen.j: そのような中で、ようやく信長から佐久間信盛、平手汎秀率いる援軍が送られてきた。
sen.e: In such a situation, reinforcements sent by Nobunaga and headed by Nobumori SAKUMA and Hirohide HIRATE arrived at long last.
In such a situation, reinforcements sent by Nobunaga and headed by Nobumori SAKUMA and Hirohide HIRATE arrived at long last.

sen.j: その間、別働隊との合流も果たし、浜松城へ近付く武田軍であったが、長期戦を嫌う信玄は浜松城を悠然と素通りして、三河国に侵攻するかのように転進した。
sen.e: Meanwhile, Takeda's troop, having merged separate bodies, was coming near to Hamamatsu-jo Castle, but disliking that the battle would be protracted, Shingen changed the direction of the troop so as to invade Mikawa Province, passing through the castle without stopping.

Meanwhile, Takeda's troops, having merged separate groups, were coming near to Hamamatsu-jo Castle, but disliking that the battle would be protracted, Shingen changed the direction of the troops so as to invade Mikawa Province, passing through the castle without stopping.

sen.j: これを聞いた家康は、織田軍の将・佐久間信盛らが籠城を唱えるのに反して武田軍を追撃。
sen.e: Hearing this, Ieyasu chased the Takeda's troop, opposing the advice of Nobumori SAKUMA, the commander of the Oda's troop, and others that they should stay in the castle.
Hearing this, Ieyasu chased the Takeda's army, opposing the advice of Nobumori SAKUMA, the commander of the Oda's army, and others that they should stay in the castle.

sen.j: しかしその結果、鳥居忠広、成瀬正義や、二俣城の戦いで開城の恥辱を雪ごうとした中根正照、青木貞治といった家臣をはじめ1,000人以上の死傷者を出し、平手汎秀といった織田軍からの援将が戦死するなど徳川・織田連合軍は惨敗した。
sen.e: However, resultantly, the allied forces of Tokugawa and Oda were defeated miserably: More than 1,000 persons, including Tadahiro TORII and Masayoshi NARUSE as well as Masateru NAKANE and Sadaharu AOKI, both of whom tried to clear the humiliation of having made the Futamata-jo Castle surrendered once, and Hirohide HIRATE, a general of Oda's reinforcements, died in the fight.

sen.j: 夏目吉信に代表される身代わりに助けられて、命からがら浜松城に逃げ帰った家康自身も、馬上で脱糞したとさえ言われている。
sen.e: Being helped by persons, including Yoshinobu NATSUME, who were killed instead of him, Ieyasu himself narrowly escaped back to Hamamatsu-jo Castle, and it is even said that he defecated on his horse on the occasion

sen.j: このとき、浜松城まで追撃された家康は「空城計」を用いた。
sen.e: On this occasion, Ieyasu, who had been chased to Hamamatsu-jo Castle, used the "Kujokei" fighting strategy (in which the gates of the castle were left open and the castle was made look inhabited).

sen.j: この計によって城の様子を怪しんだ武田軍は城内侵攻をためらい、撤退を決断したとされている。
sen.e: It is said that, becoming suspicious about the state of the castle due to this strategy, the Takeda's troop hesitated to invade the castle and decided to retreat.

sen.j: なお、この時の家康の苦渋に満ちた表情を写した肖像画（しかみ像）が残っており、これは自身の戒めのために描かせたものと伝えられる（三方ヶ原の戦い）。
sen.e: A portrait depicting his agonizing facial expression on this occasion (called Shikamizo) remains, and it is said that he made it depicted for admonishing himself (the Battle of Mikatagahara).
A portrait depicting his agonized facial expression on this occasion (called Shikamizo) remains, and it is said that he made it to admonish himself (the Battle of Mikatagahara).

sen.j: 浜名湖北岸で越年したのち三河国への進軍を再開した武田軍によって、三河国設楽郡の野田城を2月には落とされ、城主・菅沼定盈が拘束された。
sen.e: Takeda's troop stayed in the year end and new year period on the northern shore of Lake Hamana and started moving towards Mikawa Province again, and in February, Noda-jo Castle in Shitara County of Mikawa Province was seized and Sadamitsu SUGANUMA, the lord of the castle, was taken into custody.
sen.cmt: (三河国)： ウェッブ上の表現に合わせて、削除してあります。
sen.e: Takeda's troops stayed in the year end and new year period on the northern shore of Lake Hamana and started moving towards Mikawa Province again, and in February, Noda-jo Castle in Shitara County of Mikawa Province was seized and Sadamitsu SUGANUMA, the lord of the castle, was taken into custody.

sen.j: ところがその後、信玄の発病によって長篠城まで退き、一ヶ月ほど沈黙する武田軍。
sen.e: However, after that, Takeda's forces retreated to Nagashino-jo Castle due to Shingen's illness and did nothing for around a month.
However, after that, Takeda's forces retreated to Nagashino-jo Castle due to Shingen's illness and did nothing for around a month.

sen.j: 信玄の回復を待ち、西上作戦の継続を望んだ。
sen.e: The Takeda's forces desired to continue the strategy of going to west, after Shigen's health recovered.

sen.j: しかしながら、快方に向かわぬ容態のため、武田軍は作戦を断念し甲斐国へ帰還した。
sen.e: However, because his health did not seem to recover, the forces returned to Kai Province, abandoning the strategy.

sen.j: なお、信玄は帰還途中の信濃国で死去した。
sen.e: Shingen died in Shinano Province en route to returning to Kai Province.
Shingen died in Shinano Province en route to returning to Kai Province.

sen.j: 武田軍の突然の撤退は、家康に信玄死去の疑念を抱かせた。
sen.e: The sudden retreat of the Takada's forces made Ieyasu consider that Kenshin might have died.
The sudden retreat of the Takada's forces made Ieyasu consider that Kenshin might have died.

sen.j: その生死を確認するため家康は武田領である駿河国の岡部に放火し、三河国では長篠城を攻めるなどしている。
sen.e: To check whether Shingen had died or not, Ieyasu set fire in Okabe of Suruga Province, a territory of the Takeda clan, and attacked Nagashino-jo Castle in Mikawa Province.
To check whether Shingen had died or not, Ieyasu set fire in Okabe of Suruga Province, a territory of the Takeda clan, and attacked Nagashino-jo Castle in Mikawa Province.

sen.j: そしてこれら一連の行動で武田軍の抵抗がほとんどなかったことから信玄の死を確信した。
sen.e: Based on the fact that Takeda's forces made no resistance to these actions, Ieyasu firmly believed that Shingen had died.

sen.j: 家康は、武田氏に与していた奥三河の豪族で山家三方衆の一角である奥平貞能・奥平信昌親子を調略し、再属させた。
sen.e: Then he plotted Sadayoshi OKUDAIRA and Nobumasa OKUDAIRA, a father and his son, who were principal persons in one of the three dominant local clans in the Oku-Mikawa area (called Yamaga sanpo shu) and had been on the Takeda side, to rejoin the Ieyasu side.

sen.j: 奪回した長篠城には奥平軍を配し、武田軍の再侵攻に備えさせた。
sen.e: He placed Okudaira's forces in the regained Nagashino-jo Castle to prepare a new invasion of Takeda's forces.

sen.j: 天正2年（1574年）5月、信玄の後を継いだ武田勝頼が率いる2万5,000人の大軍が、遠江国の高天神城へ侵攻した。
sen.e: In May (in the old calendar) of 1574, a large troop of 25,000 persons led by Katsuyori TAKEDA, who had succeeded Shingen, attacked Takatenjin-jo Castle in Totomi Province.

sen.j: これに対して家康は単独で迎撃せず、信長に援軍を要請したが、援軍の到着前に高天神城を失った。
sen.e: For this, Ieyasu did not fight the troop independently, and asked Nobunaga for sending reinforcements, but lost Takatenjin-jo Castle before the reinforcements arrived.
For this, Ieyasu did not fight independently, and asked Nobunaga to send reinforcements, but lost Takatenjin-jo Castle before the reinforcements arrived.

sen.j: 天正3年（1575年）5月には、勝頼が率いる1万5,000人の大軍に三河国の長篠城を攻められた。
sen.e: In May (in the old calendar) of 1575, Nagashino-jo Castle in Mikawa Province was attacked by a large troop of 15,000 persons led by Katsuyori TAKEDA

sen.j: これに対して長篠城主・奥平貞昌が率いる僅か500人の将兵は善戦。
sen.e: For this, a troop of only 500 commander and soldiers led by Sadamasa OKUDAIRA fought a good fight.
For this, a troop of only 500 soldiers led by Sadamasa OKUDAIRA fought a good fight.

sen.j: 籠城軍の耐え抜きによって救援に間に合った織田・徳川連合軍は、設楽原での後詰決戦において武田軍に大勝。
sen.e: The troop having stayed in the castle endured the fight, and the allied forces of Oda and Tokugawa that arrived wan a landslide victory against the Takeda's forces in the Atozume-kessen fight (a fight between invasion forces and the reinforcements to fight with the invasion forces) at Shitaragahara

The troops that stayed in the castle endured the fight, and the allied forces of Oda and Tokugawa that arrived won a landslide victory against Takeda's forces in the Atozume-kessen fight (a fight between invasion forces and the reinforcements to fight with the invasion forces) at Shitaragahara.

sen.j: この戦いで山県昌景、馬場信春を初めとする多くの武将を討ち果たして、武田軍を壊滅させた徳川氏は、武田氏との優劣を逆転させた（長篠の戦い）。
sen.e: In this battle, the Tokugawa clan killed many military commanders of the Takeda's forces, including Masakage YAMAGATA and Nobuharu BABA, devastating the forces and becoming to occupying a position superior to that of the Takeda clan (the Battle of Nagashino).

sen.j: なお、奥平信昌（信長の偏諱を賜り信昌と改名）の戦功に対する褒美として家康は、名刀・大般若長光を授けて賞した。
sen.e: To reward the distinguished accomplishment of Nobumasa OKUDAIRA (his name had been changed to Nobumasa, with a character (信) in Nobunaga (信長)) in the battle, Ieyasu gave him a distinguished sword called Daihannya-nagamitsu (literally, a sword of great wisdom by Nagamitsu).

sen.j: その上、翌年には長女・亀姫 (盛徳院)を正室とさせている。
sen.e: In addition, Ieyasu made Kame-hime (Seitokuin), his eldest daughter, Nobumasa's legal wife in the next year.

sen.j: なおこの年、家康は武田氏に奪われていた二俣城を奪還した。
sen.e: In this year, Ieyasu regained the Futamata-jo Castle that had been taken by the Takeda clan.

sen.j: 天正7年（1579年）、信長から、正室・築山殿と嫡男・松平信康に対し、武田氏への内通疑惑がかけられた。
sen.e: In 1579, Nobunaga suspected that Ieyasu's legal wife, Tsukiyama-dono, and his heir, Nobuyasu Matsudaira, might have had secret communication with the Takeda clan.

sen.j: 家康は抗弁の使者を立てたが、信長からの要求は、信康の切腹であった。
sen.e: Ieyasu sent to Nobunaga a messenger to refute the allegation, but the demand from Nobunaga was that Nobuyasu should commit ritual suicide by disembowelment.

sen.j: 家康は熟慮の末、信長との同盟関係維持を優先し、正室を殺害し、嫡男に切腹させた。
sen.e: Giving, after serious consideration, priority to maintain the alliance with Nobunaga, Ieyasu killed his legal wife and made his heir commit ritual suicide by disembowelment.
Giving, after serious consideration, priority to maintain the alliance with Nobunaga, Ieyasu killed his legal wife and made his heir commit ritual suicide by disembowelment.

sen.j: この事件は信長が自身の嫡男・織田信忠より優れた資質を持つ信康に危機感を覚えたため等、諸説ある。
sen.e: Concerning this incident, there are various theories, including the one that Nobunaga felt a sense of crisis to Nobuyasu who had abilities superior to those of his heir, Nobutada ODA.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: しかしながら、近年では家康・信康父子が対立したためで、信長には了承を求めただけ（信康の正室が信長の娘であるため）、という説も強くなってきている。
sen.e: However, recently, the theory has become supported strongly as well that this incident was caused due to confrontations between Ieyasu and Nobuyasu, or a father and son, and Ieyasu only asked for Nobunaga's consent (because the legal wife of Nobuyasu was a daughter of Nobunaga).

sen.j: 天正9年（1581年）3月23日、武田氏によって奪われていた高天神城を奪回した。
sen.e: On March 23 (in the old calendar), 1581, Ieyasu took back Takatenjin-jo Castle that had been taken by the Takeda clan.

sen.j: 天正10年（1582年）2月、信玄の娘婿である木曾義昌が織田氏に寝返ったことを機に、信長は武田氏領国へ侵攻を開始する。
sen.e: Taking the opportunity when Yoshimasa KISO, the husband of Shingen's daughter, became to belong to the Oda clan side, Nobunaga started invading Takeda's territories in February (in the old calendar) of 1582.

sen.j: 家康は織田軍に協力し、駿河口から武田領に向かって侵攻した。
sen.e: Cooperating with Oda's forces, Ieyasu advanced his forces into Takeda's territories through the route called Suruga-guchi.
sen.cmt: 駿河口： 正しい読み、不明です。
sen.e: Cooperating with Oda's forces, Ieyasu advanced his forces into Takeda's territories through the route called Suruga-guchi.
Cooperating with Oda's forces, Ieyasu advanced his forces into Takeda's territories through the route called Suruga-guchi.

sen.j: これに対して、すでに連年の戦争による財政難などで民心が離反していた武田軍には組織的な抵抗力がなく、木曽地域口から攻め込んだ織田軍はあっという間に伊那城、松尾城を落とした。
sen.e: For these movements, no systematic resistant power remained in the Takeda's forces, from which public mind had been alienated due to financial difficulties caused by wars continued for long years, and Oda forces, which invaded Takeda's territories through the route called Kisochiiki-guchi, made Ina-jo Castle and Matsuo-jo Castle surrendered quickly.
sen.cmt: 木曽地域口： 正しい読み、不明です。
sen.e: For these movements, no systematic resistance remained in the Takeda's forces, from which public mind had been alienated due to financial difficulties caused by wars continued for long years, and Oda forces, which invaded Takeda's territories through the route called Kisochiiki-guchi, made Ina-jo Castle and Matsuo-jo Castle surrendered quickly.

For these movements, no systematic resistance remained in the Takeda's forces, from which public mind had been alienated due to financial difficulties caused by wars continued for long years, and Oda forces, which invaded Takeda's territories through the route called Kisochiiki-guchi, made Ina-jo Castle and Matsuo-jo Castle surrendered quickly.

sen.j: 徳川軍も駿河国に侵攻して依田信蕃の田中城を成瀬正一 (戦国武将)らの説得により大久保忠世が引き取った。
sen.e: Tokugawa's forces also invaded Suruga Province, and Tadayo Okubo took charge of Nobushige YODA's Tanaka-jo Castle by a persuasion of Masakazu NARUSE (a military commander in the Sengoku period) and others.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Tokugawa's forces also invaded Suruga Province, and Tadayo Okubo took charge of Nobushige YODA's Tanaka-jo Castle by a persuasion of Masakazu NARUSE (a military commander in the Sengoku period) and others.

Tokugawa's forces also invaded Suruga Province, and Tadayo OKUBO took charge of Nobushige YODA's Tanaka-jo Castle by a persuasion of Masakazu NARUSE (a military commander in the Sengoku period) and others.

sen.j: さらには武田勝頼の姉婿である穴山信君を調略によって離反させるなどして駿河国を占領した。
sen.e: In addition, Ieyasu took over Suruga Province using various means, including a plot to make Nobukimi ANAYAMA, the husband of an elder sister of Katsuyori TAKEDA, to be separated from the Takeda clan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In addition, Ieyasu took over Suruga Province using various means, including a plot to make Nobukimi ANAYAMA, the husband of an elder sister of Katsuyori TAKEDA, to be separated from the Takeda clan.
In addition, Ieyasu took over Suruga Province using various means, including a plot to make Nobukimi ANAYAMA, the husband of an elder sister of Katsuyori TAKEDA, to be separated from the Takeda clan.

sen.j: これに対して勝頼に対抗する力はなく、最後は小山田信茂にまで裏切られ、3月11日に勝頼は甲斐国東部の天目山・田野において自刃、武田氏は滅亡した（武田征伐）。
sen.e: Katsuyori had no power to resist against these situations, and being at last betrayed even by Nobushige OYAMADA, killed himself with his sword at Tano in Tenmoku-zan Mountain in the eastern part of Kai Province.

Katsuyori had no power to resist against these situations, and being at last betrayed even by Nobushige OYAMADA, killed himself with his sword at Tano in Tenmoku-zan Mountain in the eastern part of Kai Province.

Katsuyori had no power to resist against these situations, and being at last betrayed even by Nobushige OYAMADA, killed himself with his sword at Tano on Mt. Tenmoku in the eastern part of Kai Province.

sen.j: 家康はこの戦功により、信長から駿河国を与えられた。
sen.e: Due to the distinguished achievement in the war, Ieyasu was given Suruga Province by Nobunaga.
For distinguished achievement in the war, Ieyasu was given Suruga Province by Nobunaga.
For distinguished achievement in the war, Ieyasu was given Suruga Province by Nobunaga.

sen.j: 天正10年（1582年）5月、駿河国拝領の礼のため、降伏した穴山信君とともに織田信長の居城・安土城を訪れた。
sen.e: In May (in the old calendar), Ieyasu visited Azuchi-jo Castle, where Nobunaga ODA resided, to express thanks for the award of Suruga Province to him, together with Nobukimi ANAYAMA who had been surrendered.

In May (in the old calendar), Ieyasu visited Azuchi-jo Castle, where Nobunaga ODA resided, to express thanks for the award of Suruga Province to him, together with Nobukimi ANAYAMA who had been surrendered.

sen.j: 6月2日、堺で遊覧中に京都で本能寺の変が起こった。
sen.e: On June 2 (in the old calendar), while he was doing sightseeing in Sakai, Honnoji Incident occurred in Kyoto.
On June 2 (in the old calendar), while he was doing sightseeing in Sakai, the Honnoji Incident occurred in Kyoto.
On June 2 (in the old calendar), while he was doing sightseeing in Sakai, the Honnoji Incident occurred in Kyoto.

sen.j: このときの家康の供は小姓衆など少人数であった。
sen.e: At that time, Ieyasu's entourage was small, only with his guards and some others.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: At that time, Ieyasu's entourage was small, only with his guards and some others.
At that time, Ieyasu's entourage was small, only with his guards and some others.

sen.j: このため極めて危険な状態となり、一時は狼狽して信長の後を追おうとするほどであった。
sen.e: Therefore, he was placed in so dangerous a state and was also so embarrassed for a while that he considered following Nobunaga.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, he was placed in so dangerous a state and was also so embarrassed for a while that he considered following Nobunaga.
Therefore, he was placed in so dangerous a state and was also so embarrassed for a while that he considered following Nobunaga.

sen.j: しかし本多忠勝に説得され、服部半蔵の進言を受け、伊賀国の険しい山道を越え加太越を経て伊勢国から海路で三河国に辛うじて戻った（伊賀越え）。
sen.e: However, persuaded by Tadakatsu HONDA and advised by Hanzo HATTORI, Ieyasu walked steep mountain paths in Iga Province, and narrowly returned to Mikawa Province from Ise Province by sea, after crossing the Kabutogoe pass (Iga-goe (literally, passing the Iga area)).

However, persuaded by Tadakatsu HONDA and advised by Hanzo HATTORI, Ieyasu walked steep mountain paths in Iga Province, and narrowly returned to Mikawa Province from Ise Province by sea, after crossing the Kabutogoe pass (Iga-goe (literally, passing the Iga area)).

However, persuaded by Tadakatsu HONDA and advised by Hanzo HATTORI, Ieyasu walked steep mountain paths in Iga Province, and narrowly returned to Mikawa Province from Ise Province by sea, after crossing the Kabutogoe pass (Iga-goe (literally, passing the Iga area)).

sen.j: その後、家康は明智光秀を討つために軍勢を集めて尾張国にまで進軍したが、このとき中国地方から帰還した豊臣秀吉によって光秀が既に討たれたことを知った。
sen.e: After this, Ieyasu gathered his military forces to defeat Mitsuhide AKECHI and advanced them up to Owari Province, and there, he knew that Mitsuhide had already been defeated by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, who had returned from the Chugoku region.

After this, Ieyasu gathered his military forces to defeat Mitsuhide AKECHI and advanced them up to Owari Province, and there, he knew that Mitsuhide had already been defeated by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, who had returned from the Chugoku region.

After this, Ieyasu gathered his military forces to defeat Mitsuhide AKECHI and advanced them up to Owari Province, and there, he knew that Mitsuhide had already been defeated by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, who had returned from the Chugoku region.

sen.j: 一方、信長の領土となっていた旧武田領・甲斐国と信濃国では一揆が起こった。
sen.e: On the other hand, an uprising occurred in the Kai Province and Shinano Province where had been Takeda's territories formerly and was Nobunaga's territories at that time.
On the other hand, an uprising occurred in the Kai Province and Shinano Province which had been Takeda's territories formerly and were Nobunaga's territories at that time.

sen.j: さらに越後国の上杉氏、相模国の後北条氏も侵攻の気配を見せた。
sen.e: In addition, the Uesugi clan in Echigo Province and the Gohojo clan in Sagami Province showed a sign of invasion there.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In addition, the Uesugi clan in Echigo Province and the Gohojo clan in Sagami Province showed a sign of invasion there.
In addition, the Uesugi clan in Echigo Province and the Gohojo clan in Sagami Province showed a sign of invasion there.

sen.j: そのため、信濃国の森長可と毛利秀頼は領地を捨てて逃亡し、上野国の滝川一益は北条氏と戦って惨敗し、尾張国に撤退した。
sen.e: Therefore, Nagayoshi MORI (森) of Shinano Province and Hideyori MORI (毛利) fled, abandoning their respective territories, and Kazumasu TAKIGAWA of Kozuke Province was defeated by fighting with the Hojo clan and retreated to Owari Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, Nagayoshi MORI (森) of Shinano Province and Hideyori MORI (毛利) fled, abandoning their respective territories, and Kazumasu TAKIGAWA of Kozuke Province was defeated by fighting with the Hojo clan and retreated to Owari Province.

Therefore, Nagayoshi MORI (森) of Shinano Province and Hideyori MORI (毛利) fled, abandoning their respective territories, and Kazumasu TAKIGAWA of Kozuke Province was defeated by fighting with the Hojo clan and retreated to Owari Province.

sen.j: 甲斐国の領主・河尻秀隆に至っては信長の死を契機として発生した一揆に殺されてしまった（）。
sen.e: Hidetaka KAWAJIRI, the lord of Kai Province, was killed in an uprising that occurred at the opportunity of Nobunaga's death ().
Hidetaka KAWAJIRI, the lord of Kai Province, was killed in an uprising that occurred at the opportunity of Nobunaga's death ().
Hidetaka KAWAJIRI, the lord of Kai Province, was killed in an uprising that occurred at the opportunity of Nobunaga's death ().

sen.j: このため、甲斐国・信濃国・上野国は領主のいない空白地帯となった。
sen.e: Therefore, the tree provinces of Kai Province, Shinano Province, and Kozuke Province became blank areas with no lord.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, the three provinces of Kai Province, Shinano Province, and Kozuke Province became blank areas with no lord.
Therefore, the three provinces of Kai Province, Shinano Province, and Kozuke Province became blank areas with no lord.

sen.j: 家康は武田氏の遺臣・岡部正綱や依田信蕃、甲斐国の辺境武士団である武川衆らを先鋒とし、自らも8,000人の軍勢を率いて、甲斐国に攻め入った（天正壬午の乱）。
sen.e: Then, with Masatsuna OKABE and Nobushige YODA, both surviving retainers of the Takeda clan, and Mukawa-shu, a group of samurai in a marginal area in Kai Province as spearheads, Ieyasu himself invaded Kai Province, leading a military forces of 8,000 persons (Tenshojingo no ran (Tenshojingo Rebellion)).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Then, with Masatsuna OKABE and Nobushige YODA, both surviving retainers of the Takeda clan, and Mukawa-shu, a group of samurai in a marginal area in Kai Province as spearheads, Ieyasu himself invaded Kai Province, leading an army of 8,000 (Tenshojingo no ran (Tenshojingo Rebellion)).

Then, with Masatsuna OKABE and Nobushige YODA, both surviving retainers of the Takeda clan, and Mukawa-shu, a group of samurai in a marginal area in Kai Province as spearheads, Ieyasu himself invaded Kai Province, leading an army of 8,000 (Tenshojingo no ran (Tenshojingo Rebellion)).

sen.j: 一方、甲斐国と信濃国が空白地帯となったのを見た相模国の北条氏直も、叔父・北条氏規や北条氏照ら5万5,000人の軍勢を率いて碓氷峠を越えて信濃国に侵攻した。
sen.e: On the other hand, Ujinao HOJO of Sagami Province, who had known that both Kai Province and Shinano Province became blank areas, invaded Shinano Province across Usui-toge Pass, leading a military forces of 55,000 persons, including Ujinori HOJO, his uncle, and Ujiteru HOJO.

On the other hand, Ujinao HOJO of Sagami Province, who had known that both Kai Province and Shinano Province became blank areas, invaded Shinano Province across Usui-toge Pass, leading an army of 55,000, including Ujinori HOJO, his uncle, and Ujiteru HOJO.

sen.j: 北条軍は上杉軍と川中島で対峙した後に和睦し、南へ進軍した。
sen.e: Hojo's forces confronted Uesugi's ones at Kawanakajima, but made peace with them later and advanced southwards.
Hojo's forces confronted Uesugi's ones at Kawanakajima, but made peace with them later and advanced southwards.

sen.j: 徳川軍は、この北条軍と新府城、若神子で対陣。
sen.e: Tokugawa's forces encamped in Shinpu-jo Castle and at Wakamiko, facing the Hojo's ones.
Tokugawa's forces encamped in Shinpu-jo Castle and at Wakamiko, facing the Hojo's ones.
Tokugawa's forces encamped in Shinpu-jo Castle and at Wakamiko, facing the Hojo's ones.

sen.j: ここに徳川軍と北条軍の全面対決の様相を呈した。
sen.e: Here, the state became to look like a full-scale war between Tokugawa's forces and Hojo's ones.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Here, the state came to look like a full-scale war between Tokugawa's forces and Hojo's.
Here, the state came to look like a full-scale war between Tokugawa's forces and Hojo's.

sen.j: しかしながら、依田信蕃の調略を受けて真田昌幸が徳川軍に寝返った。
sen.e: However, through a plot by Nobushige YODA, Masayuki SANADA changed his side so as to support Tokugawa's forces
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, through a plot by Nobushige YODA, Masayuki SANADA changed his side so as to support Tokugawa's forces.
However, through a plot by Nobushige YODA, Masayuki SANADA changed his side so as to support Tokugawa's forces.

sen.j: その執拗なゲリラ戦法の前に戦意を喪失した北条軍は、板部岡江雪斎を使者として家康に和睦を求めた。
sen.e: Due to Tokugawa forces' persistent guerrilla tactics, the Hojo's forces lost the will to fight, and sent Kosetsusai ITABEOKA to Ieyasu seeking to make peace with Tokugawa's forces.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Due to the Tokugawa forces' persistent guerrilla tactics, the Hojo forces lost the will to fight, and sent Kosetsusai ITABEOKA to Ieyasu seeking to make peace with Tokugawa's forces.
Due to the Tokugawa forces' persistent guerrilla tactics, the Hojo forces lost the will to fight, and sent Kosetsusai ITABEOKA to Ieyasu seeking to make peace with Tokugawa's forces.

sen.j: 和睦の条件は、上野国を北条氏が、甲斐国・信濃国を徳川氏がそれぞれ領有し、家康の次女・督姫が氏直に嫁ぐというものであった。
sen.e: Conditions of making the peace were that the Hojo clan should own Kozuke Province and the Tokugawa clan Kai Province and Shinano Province, and that Tokuhime, the second daughter of Ieyasu, should marry Ujinao

sen.j: こうして、家康は北条氏と縁戚・同盟関係を結び、同時に甲斐国・信濃国・駿河国・遠江国・三河国の5か国を領有する大大名へとのし上がった。
sen.e: In this way, Ieyasu established a relationship by blood with and an alliance also with the Hojo clan, and at the same time, advanced to a big daimyo who owned the five provinces of Kai, Shinano, Suruga, Totomi, and Mikawa.

In this way, Ieyasu established a relationship by blood with and an alliance also with the Hojo clan, and at the same time, advanced to a big daimyo who owned the five provinces of Kai, Shinano, Suruga, Totomi, and Mikawa.

sen.j: 信長死後の天正11年（1583年）、織田氏筆頭家老であった柴田勝家を賤ヶ岳の戦いで破った豊臣秀吉が台頭する。
sen.e: In 1583 after Nobunaga's death, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI defeated Katsuie SHIBATA, who had been the chief karo (the highest officer of a family) of the Oda family, a the Battle of Shizugatake, and became to gain power..

In 1583 after Nobunaga's death, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI defeated Katsuie SHIBATA, who had been the chief karo (the highest officer of a family) of the Oda family, a the Battle of Shizugatake, and came to gain power.

In 1583 after Nobunaga's death, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI defeated Katsuie SHIBATA, who had been the chief karo (the highest officer of a family) of the Oda family, the Battle of Shizugatake, and came to gain power.
sen.cmt: 不要な単語を削除しました。

sen.j: 家康は信長の次男・織田信雄と手を結び、これに対抗した。
sen.e: Ieyasu allied with Nobukatsu ODA, the second son of Nobunaga, and confronted Hideyoshi.
Ieyasu allied with Nobukatsu ODA, the second son of Nobunaga, and confronted Hideyoshi.
Ieyasu allied with Nobukatsu ODA, the second son of Nobunaga, and confronted Hideyoshi.
sen.cmt: スペース削除しました。

sen.j: そして徳川・織田連合軍は天正12年（1584年）3月、尾張小牧において羽柴軍と対峙した。
sen.e: Then in March (in the old calendar) of 1584, the allied forces of Tokugawa and Oda faced Hashiba's ones at Komaki in Owari.
Then in March (in the old calendar) of 1584, the allied forces of Tokugawa and Oda faced Hashiba's ones at Komaki in Owari.
Then in March (in the old calendar) of 1584, the allied forces of Tokugawa and Oda faced Hashiba's ones at Komaki in Owari.

sen.j: このとき、羽柴軍の兵力は10万人、徳川・織田連合軍は5万人であった。
sen.e: On this occasion, the number of soldiers of the Hashiba's forces was 100,000, while that of the allied forces of Tokugawa and Oda was 50,000.
On this occasion, the number of soldiers of the Hashiba's forces was 100,000, while that of the allied forces of Tokugawa and Oda was 50,000.
On this occasion, the number of soldiers of the Hashiba's forces was 100,000, while that of the allied forces of Tokugawa and Oda was 50,000.

sen.j: 家康は兵力的に不利であったが、秀吉が小牧市に到着する前に羽柴軍の武将・森長可率いる軍勢を酒井忠次に命じて撃破させた（羽黒の戦い）。
sen.e: Although Ieyasu was placed in a disadvantageous position in view of military forces, he made Tadatsugu SAKAI defeat the troop led by Nagayoshi MORI, a military commander of the Hashiba's forces, before Hideyoshi arrived at Komaki City (the Battle of Haguro).
sen.cmt: 小牧・長久手の戦い羽黒の戦い： ウェッブ上の表現”羽黒の戦い”に置き換えた上で、訳しています。
sen.e: Although Ieyasu was placed in a disadvantageous position in view of military forces, he made Tadatsugu SAKAI defeat the troop led by Nagayoshi MORI, a military commander of the Hashiba's forces, before Hideyoshi arrived at Komaki City (the Battle of Haguro).

Although Ieyasu was placed in a disadvantageous position in view of military forces, he made Tadatsugu SAKAI defeat the troop led by Nagayoshi MORI, a military commander of the Hashiba's forces, before Hideyoshi arrived at Komaki City (the Battle of Haguro).

sen.j: 秀吉率いる羽柴軍本隊は犬山城に入り徳川軍と対峙し、膠着状態に陥った
sen.e: The main body of the Hashiba's forces, led by Hideyoshi, entered Inuyama-jo Castle and faced the Tokugawa's forces, and then the battle become deadlocked.
The main body of the Hashiba's forces, led by Hideyoshi, entered Inuyama-jo Castle and faced the Tokugawa's forces, and then the battle become deadlocked.
The main body of the Hashiba's forces, led by Hideyoshi, entered Inuyama-jo Castle and faced the Tokugawa's forces, and then the battle become deadlocked.

sen.j: 羽柴軍の武将・森長可とその義父・池田恒興が岡崎城を奇襲すべく、豊臣秀次（羽柴秀次）を総大将とする別動隊を率いて出陣した。
sen.e: To make Nagayoshi MORI, a military commander of the Hashiba's forces, and Tsuneoki IKEDA, his father-in-law, raid Okazaki-jo Castle, a military troop separate from the main body, with Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI (Hidetsugu HASHIBA) as the supreme commander, started moving.

To make Nagayoshi MORI, a military commander of the Hashiba's forces, and Tsuneoki IKEDA, his father-in-law, raid Okazaki-jo Castle, a military troop separate from the main body, with Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI (Hidetsugu HASHIBA) as the supreme commander, started moving.

To make Nagayoshi MORI, a military commander of the Hashiba's forces, and Tsuneoki IKEDA, his father-in-law, raid Okazaki-jo Castle, a military troop separate from the main body, with Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI (Hidetsugu HASHIBA) as the supreme commander, started moving.

sen.j: しかし家康は別働隊の動きを察知し、逆に自ら羽柴別働隊に奇襲をかけて殲滅し、豊臣秀次を敗走させ、恒興、長可、池田元助（恒興の嫡男）らを討ち取った（小牧・長久手の戦い）。
sen.e: However, Ieyasu detected the movement of Hidetsugu's military troop, and raided and annihilated the troop by himself, making Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI take to flight and killing Tsuneoki, Nagayoshi, and Motosuke IKEDA (the heir of Tsuneoki) (Battle of Komaki-Nagakute)
sen.cmt: （小牧・長久手の戦い中入り）： ウェッブ上の表現に合わせて、削除してあいます。
sen.e: However, Ieyasu detected the movement of Hidetsugu's military troops, and raided and annihilated the troops by himself, making Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI take to flight and killing Tsuneoki, Nagayoshi, and Motosuke IKEDA (the heir of Tsuneoki) (Battle of Komaki-Nagakute)

However, Ieyasu detected the movement of Hidetsugu's military troops, and raided and annihilated the troops by himself, making Hidetsugu TOYOTOMI take to flight and killing Tsuneoki, Nagayoshi, and Motosuke IKEDA (the heir of Tsuneoki) (Battle of Komaki-Nagakute).
sen.cmt: ピリオド補足しました。

sen.j: これを機に、秀吉は家康を正攻法で打ち破ることは困難と判断し、伊勢国の織田信雄を攻めた。
sen.e: After this, Hideyoshi came to consider that it would be difficult to defeat Ieyasu using regular tactics for attack, and attacked Nobukatsu in Ise Province.
After this, Hideyoshi came to consider that it would be difficult to defeat Ieyasu using regular tactics for attack, and attacked Nobukatsu in Ise Province.

sen.j: 織田軍には単独で羽柴軍と対抗できる力はなく、秀吉と単独講和してしまった。
sen.e: Because Oda's forces had not the power enough to confront Hashiba's ones, Nobukatsu made peace with Hideyoshi.

sen.j: 家康は小牧・長久手の戦いの大義名分を「信長の遺児である信雄を助けて、秀吉を討つ」としていた。
sen.e: Ieyasu's legitimate reason for the fight at Battle of Komaki-Nagakute was that "He should defeat Hideyoshi to help Nobukatsu, a bereaved child of Nobunaga."

sen.j: そのため、信雄が秀吉と講和したことで名分を失った家康は撤退を余儀なくされた。
sen.e: Therefore, he lost the reason because Nobukatsu made peace with Hideyoshi, and was forced to retreat his forces.

sen.j: そして秀吉との講和条件として、次男の於義丸（後の結城秀康）を秀吉の養子とすることで大坂に送った。
sen.e: Then as a term of making peace with Hideyoshi, he made his second son, Ogimaru, adopted by Hideyoshi and sent Ogimaru to Osaka.

sen.j: 天正13年（1585年）に入ると、紀伊国の雑賀衆や土佐国の長宗我部元親、越中国の佐々成政など、前年の小牧・長久手の戦いで家康に味方した勢力は、秀吉によってことごとく討伐された。
sen.e: Entering 1585, all of the powers that assisted Ieyasu in Battle of Komaki-Nagakute in the previous year, such as Saika-shu in Kii Province, Motochika CHOSOKABE in Tosa Province, and Narimasa SASSA in Ecchu Province, were defeated by Hideyoshi.

sen.j: このため秀吉との対立で不利になった家康は、相模国の北条氏との同盟関係を強化するため、上野国・沼田市を割譲することを約束した。
sen.e: Having been placed in a disadvantageous position in confrontation with Hideyoshi, Ieyasu promised to give Numata City in Kozuke Province to the Hojo clan, to strengthen the alliance with the clan in Sagami Province.

sen.j: ところが、沼田を支配していた信濃国・上田城主・真田昌幸はこれに応じず、家康から離反して越後国の上杉氏に寝返った。
sen.e: However, Masayuki SANADA, the lord of Ueda-jo Castle in Shinano Province, who had controlled Numata, did no accept the condition, and became to belong to the Uesugi clan in Echigo Province, separated from Ieyasu's side.

sen.j: これに対して家康は、大久保忠世や鳥居元忠を大将とした7,000人の軍勢を派遣し真田氏を攻めた。
sen.e: For this, Ieyasu sent a military forces of 7,000 persons with Tadayo OKUBO and Mototada TORII as the generals to attack the Sanada clan.

sen.j: しかしながら、真田軍の巧妙な戦術の前に大敗を喫し、さらに上杉氏の援軍が来たこともあって、撤兵を余儀なくされた（第一次上田合戦）。
sen.e: However, his forces were severely defeated by Sanada's forces that used dexterous tactics, and with reinforcements of the Uesugi clan arriving as well, were forced to retreat (the first Battle of Ueda).

sen.j: また、この頃になると徳川家中は、酒井忠次・本多忠勝ら反秀吉の強硬派と、石川数正ら秀吉支持の穏健派が対立し、分裂の危機にあった。
sen.e: Around this time, anti-Hideyoshi hardliners, such as Tadatsugu SAKAI and Tadakatsu HONDA, confronted soft-liners supporting Hideyoshi, such as Kazumasa ISHIKAWA, within the Tokugawa family, making the family face the crisis that it might be split.

sen.j: その結果、数正が徳川氏から出奔して豊臣氏に寝返り、家康は窮地に陥った。
sen.e: Resultantly, Kazumasa left the Tokugawa family to support the Toyotomi side, forcing Ieyasu into a corner.
Resultantly, Kazumasa left the Tokugawa family to support the Toyotomi side, forcing Ieyasu into a corner.

sen.j: この事件で徳川軍の機密が筒抜けになったことから、軍制を武田軍を見習ったものに改革していった。
sen.e: Because military secrets of Tokugawa's forces leaked out completely, he changed his military system into the one he had learnt from Takeda's forces.

sen.j: 天正14年（1586年）4月23日、秀吉からの臣従要求を拒み続ける家康に対して、秀吉は実妹・朝日姫を正室として差し出した。
sen.e: For Ieyasu who continued refusing Hideyoshi's request that Ieyasu should become a vassal serving him, Hideyoshi proposed on April 23 (in the old calendar), 1586, that he would make his younger sister, Asahihime, Ieyasu's legal wife.

sen.j: 当時、家康には正室がいなかったためである。
sen.e: At that time, Ieyasu had no legal wife.

sen.j: 5月14日、家康は朝日姫は結婚するが、なおも臣従しようとしなかった。
sen.e: On May 14, Ieyasu married Asahihime, but still refused to become a vassal of Hideyoshi.

sen.j: しかし10月18日、秀吉が生母・大政所までも人質として岡崎城に送ってきたため、遂に秀吉に臣従することを決意する。
sen.e: However, because Hideyoshi sent his biological mother, Omandokoro (the honorary term for her), to Okazaki-jo Castle on October 18 (in the old calendar) as a hostage, Ieyasu made up his mind to become a vassal of Hideyoshi.

sen.j: 10月20日に岡崎を出立し、10月26日に大坂に到着、豊臣秀長邸に宿泊した。
sen.e: Starting out from Okazaki on October 20, Ieyasu arrived in Osaka on October 26 and stayed in Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI's residence.

sen.j: その夜には秀吉本人が家康に秘かに会いに来て、改めて臣従を求めた。
sen.e: In that night, Hideyoshi himself visited Ieyasu secretly to asked Ieyasu to become his vassal.

sen.j: こうして家康は完全に秀吉に屈することとなり、10月27日、大坂城にて秀吉に謁見し、諸大名の前で豊臣氏に臣従することを表明した。
sen.e: In this way, Ieyasu became to be completely subjugated to Hideyoshi, and on October 27, Ieyasu had an audience with Hideyoshi, declaring before the daimyo gathered there that he would become a vassal serving the Toyotomi clan.

In this way, Ieyasu became completely subjugated to Hideyoshi, and on October 27, Ieyasu had an audience with Hideyoshi at Osaka-jo Castle, declaring before the daimyo gathered there that he would become a vassal serving the Toyotomi clan.

sen.j: 天正14年（1586年）11月1日、家康は京都に赴き、11月5日に正三位に叙任される。
sen.e: On November 1 (in the old calendar), 1586, Ieyasu visited Kyoto, and was awarded the rank of Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank) on November 5.

sen.j: 11月11日には三河国に帰還し、11月12日には大政所を秀吉のもとへ送り返している。
sen.e: On November 11 (in the old calendar), he retuned to Mikawa Province, and sent Omandokoro back to Hideyoshi on November 12.
On November 11 (in the old calendar), he returned to Mikawa Province, and sent Omandokoro back to Hideyoshi on November 12.

sen.j: 12月4日、家康は本城を17年間過ごした浜松城から隣国・駿河国の駿府城へ移した。
sen.e: On December 4 (in the old calendar), Ieyasu moved this main castle from Hamamatsu-jo Castle to Sunpu-jo Castle in adjacent Suruga Province.

On December 4 (in the old calendar), Ieyasu moved his main castle from Hamamatsu-jo Castle where he had spent 17 years to Sunpu-jo Castle in adjacent Suruga Province.

sen.j: これは、出奔した石川数正が浜松城の軍事機密を知り尽くしていたため、それに備えたとする説がある。
sen.e: There is the theory that this measure was taken because Kazumasa ISHIKAWA, who had left the Ieyasu side, possessed complete military secrets of Hamamatsu-jo Castle.

sen.j: 天正15年（1587年）8月、家康は再び上洛し、8月8日に従二位、大納言に叙任され、武蔵大納言と呼ばれた。
sen.e: In August (in the old calendar) of 1587, Ieyasu came to Kyoto again, and was conferred to Junii (Junior Second Rank) and Dainagon (Major Counselor) on August 8, becoming to be called Musashi-Dainagon.

sen.j: この際、秀吉から羽柴の名字を称すことも許された。
sen.e: On this occasion, he was allowed by Hideyoshi to use the name of Hashiba.

sen.e: After this, Ieyasu made efforts, based on a relationship by blood with the Hojo clan, to mediate between Hideyoshi and the clan, for example, by making Ujinori HOJO, a younger brother of Ujimasa HOJO and Ieyasu's long-time friend, come to Kyoto.

sen.e: However, Ujinao HOJO refused to serve Hideyoshi as his vassal, and in 1590, Hideyoshi started attacking the Hojo clan.

sen.j: これは150万石から250万石への類を見ない大幅な加増ではあった。

sen.e: However, it is considered that this change of territories was distress for him, because he lost the Mikawa Province to which he had been firmly related, and because in addition, there were disquieting movements in the Kanto region of that time, for example, by remaining retainers of the Hojo clan.

sen.j: しかも北条氏は四公六民という当時としては極めて低い税率を採用しており、これをむやみに上げる訳にもいかなかった。
sen.e: Furthermore, the Hojo clan employed a tax system of shiko-rokumin (the 40% of the rice crop produced yearly was collected as a tax, and the remaining 60% became farmers' income), which was extremely favorable for farmers of that time, and Ieyasu could not raise the tax rate thoughtlessly either.

sen.j: 文禄元年（1592年）より、秀吉の命により文禄・慶長の役が開始されるが、家康は渡海することなく名護屋城に在陣することだけで許された。
sen.e: In 1592, the Bunroku-Keicho War was started according to an order of Hideyoshi, but Ieyasu was allowed to stay in Nagoya-jo Castle (名護屋城), without crossing the sea.
In 1592, the Bunroku-Keicho War was started according to an order of Hideyoshi, but Ieyasu was allowed to stay in Nagoya-jo Castle, without crossing the sea.

sen.j: 『常山紀談』には、本多正信の「殿は渡海なされますか」との問いに家康が「箱根を誰に守らせるのか」と答えたエピソードを残している。
sen.e: In Jozankidan (a collection of anecdotes compiled in the Edo period), the following episode is recorded: When asked that "Do you cross the sea?" he replied that "Then who should guard Hakone?"
In Jozankidan (a collection of anecdotes compiled in the Edo period), the following episode is recorded: When asked that "Do you cross the sea?" he replied that "Then who should guard Hakone?"
In "Jozankidan" (a collection of anecdotes compiled in the Edo period), the following episode is recorded: When asked that 'Do you cross the sea?' he replied that 'Then who should guard Hakone?'

sen.j: 渡海せずに済んだのは、小田原の役で先鋒を務めたための優遇措置との見方もある。
sen.e: There is a viewpoint that he was allowed not to cross the sea as a preferential treatment, because his forces acted as a spearhead in the Siege of Odawara.
There is a viewpoint that he was allowed not to cross the sea as a preferential treatment, because his forces acted as a spearhead in the Siege of Odawara.
There is a viewpoint that he was allowed not to cross the sea as a preferential treatment, because his forces acted as a spearhead in the Siege of Odawara.

sen.j: 「際限なき軍役」といって苦しんだ文禄・慶長の役で渡海を免れた。
sen.e: In the Bunroku-Keicho War in which people agonized for "unbounded military services," he could avoid crossing the sea.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the Bunroku-Keicho War in which people agonized for "unbounded military services," he could avoid crossing the sea.
In the Bunroku-Keicho War in which people agonized for 'unbounded military services,' he could avoid crossing the sea.

sen.j: そのために、家康は兵力と財力の消耗を免れ、自国を固めることができた。
sen.e: Therefore, Ieyasu could avoid consuming his military as well as financial power, enabling him to solidify the bases of his territories.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, Ieyasu could avoid consuming his military as well as financial power, enabling him to solidify the bases of his territories.
Therefore, Ieyasu could avoid consuming his military as well as financial power, enabling him to solidify the bases of his territories.

sen.j: しかし、渡海を免除されたのは家康だけではなく、一部の例外を除くと東国の大名は名護屋残留であった。
sen.e: However, it was not only Ieyasu who could avoid crossing the sea, but most of the daimyo in the eastern areas of Japan, except rare cases, stayed at Nagoya.

sen.j: 文禄4年（1595年）7月に「秀次事件」が起きた。
sen.e: In July (in the old calendar) of 1596, the "Hidetsugu incident" occurred.
In July (in the old calendar) of 1596, the "Hidetsugu incident" occurred.
In July (in the old calendar) of 1595, the 'Hidetsugu incident' occurred.
sen.cmt: 記号を修正しました。年号修正しました。

sen.j: 豊臣政権を揺るがす大事件を受けて、豊臣秀吉は諸大名に上洛を命じ、事態の鎮静化を図った。
sen.e: After such a big incident as having shaken the Toyotomi government occurred, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI ordered all Daimyo to come to Kyoto to make the situation calm down
After such a big incident as having shaken the Toyotomi government occurred, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI ordered all Daimyo to come to Kyoto to make the situation calm down.
After such a big incident as having shaken the Toyotomi government occurred, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI ordered all Daimyo to come to Kyoto to make the situation calm down.

sen.j: 家康も豊臣秀吉の命で上洛したが、これ以降は開発途上の居城・江戸城よりも、伏見城に滞在する期間が長くなった。
sen.e: Ieyasu as well came to Kyoto responding to Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI's order, and after this, stayed in Fushimi-jo Castle longer than in the Edo-jo Castle that was his residence as well but was under development then.

Ieyasu as well came to Kyoto responding to Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI's order, and after this, stayed in Fushimi-jo Castle longer than in the Edo-jo Castle that was his residence as well but was under development then.

Ieyasu as well came to Kyoto responding to Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI's order, and after this, stayed in Fushimi-jo Castle longer than in the Edo-jo Castle that was his residence as well but was under development then.

sen.j: 豊臣政権における家康の立場が高まっていたのは明らかだが、家康自身も政権の中枢に身を置くことにより、中央政権の政治システムを直接学ぶことになった。
sen.e: Having certainly become to occupy higher positions in the Toyotomi government, Ieyasu learnt the political system in the central government through placing himself in the core of the government.
Having certainly come to occupy higher positions in the Toyotomi government, Ieyasu learned the political system in the central government through placing himself in the core of the government.
Having certainly come to occupy higher positions in the Toyotomi government, Ieyasu learned the political system in the central government through placing himself in the core of the government.

sen.j: 慶長3年（1598年）、秀吉は病に倒れると、後継者である豊臣秀頼の体制を磐石にするため、7月に五大老・五奉行の制度を定め、五大老の一人に家康を任命した。
sen.e: After having been laid up with illness, Hideyoshi specified the system of Go-tairo and Go-bugyo (five elders and five government officers) to make the government system more solid for Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, the heir of Hideyoshi, in July (in the old calendar), and appointed Ieyasu to one of the Go-tairo.

After having been laid up with illness, Hideyoshi specified the system of Go-tairo and Go-bugyo (five elders and five government officers) to make the government system more solid for Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, the heir of Hideyoshi, in July (in the old calendar), and appointed Ieyasu to one of the Go-tairo.

After having been laid up with illness, Hideyoshi specified the system of Go-tairo and Go-bugyo (five elders and five government officers) to make the government system more solid for Hideyori TOYOTOMI, the heir of Hideyoshi, in July (in the old calendar), and appointed Ieyasu to one of the Go-tairo.

sen.j: そして8月、秀吉は死去した。
sen.e: Then Hideyoshi died in August (in the old calendar).
Then Hideyoshi died in August (in the old calendar).
Then Hideyoshi died in August (in the old calendar).

sen.j: 豊臣秀吉の死後、家康は「秀頼が成人するまで政事を家康に託す」という秀吉の遺言により専横の兆しを見せ始める。
sen.e: After Hideyoshi died, Ieyasu began showing signs of tyrannical behaviors, based on Hideyoshi's will that "Governmental affairs should be entrusted to Ieyasu until Hideyori became an adult.

sen.e: Furthermore, although making marriages among daimyo was prohibited in August before Hideyoshi's death, Ieyasu arranged such marriages, starting increasing his supporters dexterously.

sen.j: さらに家康は、細川忠興や島津義弘、増田長盛らの屋敷にも頻繁に訪問して、多数派工作を行った。

sen.j: こうした政権運営をめぐって、大老・前田利家や五奉行の石田三成らの反感を買い、慶長4年（1599年）1月19日、家康に対して三中老の堀尾吉晴らが問罪使として派遣された。
sen.e: Concerning such operations of the government, Ieyasu aroused antipathy of Toshiie MAEDA, tairo (the person at the highest post of the government), and Mitsunari ISHIDA, one of Go-bugyo, and on January 19 (in the old calendar), 1599, Yoshiharu HORIO, San-churo (an arbitrator), was sent to Ieyasu as an envoy for checking the crime.

sen.j: しかしながら、吉晴らを恫喝して追い返したと言われている。
sen.e: However, it is said that Ieyasu intimidated Yoshiharu and others to make them go away.

sen.j: しかし、利家らと対立する不利を悟って、2月2日には誓書を交わして和解したが、3月3日に利家は病死した。
sen.e: However, becoming aware of that it would be disadvantageous to confront Toshiie and others, Ieyasu reconciled with them by exchanging reconciliation agreements on February 2 (in the old calendar), but Toshiie died on March 3 (in the old calendar).

sen.j: その後、福島正則や加藤清正らが三成を襲撃する事件が発生し、正則ら武断派と、三成ら文治派による対立が表面化した。
sen.e: After that, the incident in which Masanori FUKUSHIMA and Kiyomasa KATO assaulted Mitsunari occurred, making come to that surface confrontations between Budan-ha (a political faction that was willing to resort to military means to achieve its aims) of Masanori and others and Bunchi-ha (the civilian government group) of Mitsunari and others.

sen.j: 家康は武断派諸将を慰撫してその支持を集めるとともに、三成を奉行から解任して、佐和山城で蟄居させた。
sen.e: Ieyasu consoled military commanders belonging to Budan-ha to get support of them, and in addition, made Mitsunari resign from the bugyo post and made him stay in Sawayama-jo Castle.

sen.j: 9月7日、家康は大坂に入り、三成の大坂屋敷を宿所とした。
sen.e: On September 7, Ieyasu entered Osaka and stayed in the Osaka residence of Mitsunari.
On September 7, Ieyasu entered Osaka and stayed in the Osaka residence of Mitsunari.

sen.j: 9月9日に登城して豊臣秀頼に対し、重陽の節句における祝意を述べた。
sen.e: On September 9, he visited the castle and expressed his congratulations on Chrysanthemum Festival.
On September 9, he visited the castle and expressed his congratulations on Chrysanthemum Festival.

sen.j: そしてそのまま大坂に居座って、政務を執り続けた。
sen.e: Then staying in Osaka, he continued doing his governmental jobs there.

sen.j: 9月12日には三成の兄・石田正澄の大坂屋敷に移り、9月28日には大坂城・西の丸に移り、大坂で政務を執り続けた。
sen.e: On September 12, he moved to the Osaka residence of Masazumi ISHIDA, an elder brother of Mitsunari, and moved to Nishino-maru (the west compound of Osaka-jo Castle), continuing doing his governmental jobs in Osaka.

sen.j: さらに家康はこの頃、豊臣政権における諸大名の切り崩し工作も行なった。
sen.e: In addition, around this time, Ieyasu also tried breaking the ties among daimyo in the Toyotomi government secretly.

sen.j: 9月9日に登城した際、前田利長（前田利家の嫡男）・浅野長政・大野治長・土方雄久の4名が家康の暗殺計画を企んだとして、10月2日に長政を甲斐国・府中で隠居の上、蟄居させ、治長は下総国の結城秀康のもとに、雄久は常陸国・水戸市の佐竹義宣 (右京大夫)のもとへ追放とした。
sen.e: Ieyasu accused the four persons of Toshinaga MAEDA (the heir of Toshiie MAEDA), Nagamasa ASANO, Harunaga ONO, and Katsuhisa HIJIKATA of having been attempting to kill him when he was entering the castle on September 9, and on October 2, made Nagamasa retire from his active life and stay in Fuchu of Kai Province, made Nagaharu exiled to the place of Hideyasu YUKI in Shimosa Province, and made Katsuhisa exiled to the place of Yoshinobu SATAKE, (Ukyo no daibu (mayor of the right capital district)) in Mito City of Hitachi Province.

Ieyasu accused the four persons of Toshinaga MAEDA (the heir of Toshiie MAEDA), Nagamasa ASANO, Harunaga ONO, and Katsuhisa HIJIKATA of attempting to kill him when he was entering the castle on September 9, and on October 2, made Nagamasa retire from his active life and stay in Fuchu of Kai Province, made Nagaharu exiled to the place of Hideyasu YUKI in Shimosa Province, and made Katsuhisa exiled to the place of Yoshinobu SATAKE, (Ukyo no daibu (mayor of the right capital district)) in Mito City of Hitachi Province.

sen.j: さらに利長に対しては加賀国征伐を強行しようとしたが、利長が生母・芳春院（まつ）を江戸に人質として差し出したことで出兵を取りやめた。
sen.e: Furthermore, he tried to conquer Toshinaga's Kaga Province forcibly, but stopped sending his force, because Toting decided to send his real mother, Hoshunin (Matsu), to Edo as a hostage.

sen.j: しかし、これを機に前田氏は完全に家康の支配下に組み込まれた。
sen.e: However, after this, the Maeda clan became to be completely integrated into the control of Ieyasu.
However, after this, the Maeda clan became to be completely integrated into the control of Ieyasu.

sen.j: さらに家康は多数派工作も行なった。

sen.j: 対馬国・宗義智に1万石を加増。
sen.e: He increased the earning base of Yoshitoshi SO in Tsushima province to 10,000 koku.

sen.j: 遠江国・浜松12万石の堀尾吉晴に、越前国・府中5万石を加増。
sen.e: He additionally gave the 50,000 koku of Fuchu in Echizen Province to Yoshiharu HORIO who had already owned an earning base of 120,000 koku in Hamamatsu of Totomi Province.

sen.j: 美濃国・金山7万石の森忠政を、信濃国・川中島13万7,000石に加増移封。
sen.e: Tadamasa MORI who had owned 70,000-koku Kanayama in Mino Province was moved to own a bigger territory of 137,0000-koku Kawanakajima in Shinano Province

sen.j: 丹後国・宮津の細川忠興に、豊後国・杵築6万石を加増。
sen.e: Tadaoki HOSOKAWA in Miyazu, Tango Province, was moved to a bigger territory of 60,000-koku Kitsuki in Bungo Province.

sen.e: An additional territory of 50,000 koku was given to the Shimazu clan in Osumi, Satsuma Province.

sen.j: 慶長5年（1600年）3月、越後国の堀秀治、出羽国の最上義光らから、会津の上杉景勝に軍備を増強する不穏な動きがあるという知らせを受けた。
sen.e: In March (in the old calendar) of 1600, Ieyasu was informed by Hideharu HORI in Echigo Province and by Yoshiaki MOGAMI in Dewa Province that Kagekatsu UESUGI in Aizu Province was making a disquieting movement of increasing armaments.

sen.j: 上杉氏の家臣で津川城城代を務め、家康とも懇意にあった藤田信吉が会津から出奔し、江戸の徳川秀忠のもとへ「上杉氏に叛意あり」と訴えるという事件も起きた。
sen.e: The following incident occurred as well: Nobuyoshi FUJITA, who had been a retainer of the Uesugi clan, had worked as the Jodai officer (the officer sent for controlling the castle) in Tsugawa-jo Castle and had been intimate with Ieyasu as well, left the Aizu side and came to inform Hidetada TOKUGAWA that "The Uesugi clan had an intention against the central government."

sen.j: これに対して家康は伊奈昭綱を正使として景勝のもとへ問罪使を派遣した。
sen.e: For this, Ieyasu sent Akitsuna INA to Kagekatsu, as the official envoy for checking the crime.

sen.j: ところが景勝の重臣・直江兼続が「直江状」と呼ばれる挑戦状を返書として送った。
sen.e: However, Kanetsugu NAOE, a senior vassal to Kagekatsu, sent back a letter of defiance called "the Naoe Letter."

sen.j: 家康は激怒し、景勝に叛意があることは明確であるとして上杉氏討伐を宣言した。
sen.e: Then becoming seriously angry about the situation, Ieyasu declared that he should conquer the Uesugi clan, because Kagekatsu's intention of defiance was apparent.

sen.j: このとき、前田玄以・長束正家・増田長盛ら三奉行と堀尾吉晴・中村一氏・生駒親正らが征伐の中止を訴えたが聞き入れず、征伐を強行した。
sen.e: On this occasion, the three bugyo officers of Geni MAEDA, of Masaie NAGATSUKA, and of Nagamori MASHITA, Yoshiharu HORIO, Kazuuji NAKAMURA, and Chikamasa IKOMA appealed him to stop the conquering movement, but Ieyasu executed the conquering activity forcibly, without accepting the appeal..

sen.j: これに際して後陽成天皇から出馬慰労として晒布が下賜され、豊臣秀頼からは黄金2万両・兵糧米2万石を下賜された。
sen.e: For the activity, he was awarded bleached cloths by Emperor Goyozei as a recognition of sending his forces to the battle, and Hideyori TOYOTOMI awarded him a 10,000 ryo (ryo: a monetary unit at that time) of gold and a 20,000 koku of rice crop for soldiers.

sen.j: これにより、朝廷・豊臣氏から家康の上杉氏征伐は「豊臣氏の忠臣である家康が、謀反人の景勝を討つ」という義戦と認められた形となった。
sen.e: In these ways, the conquest by Ieyasu of the Uesugi clan was recognized by the Imperial court and the Toyotomi clan as a righteous fight in which "Ieyasu, a faithful retainer of the Toyotomi clan, defeated Kagekatsu, a traitor. "

sen.j: 6月16日、家康は大坂城・京橋口より軍勢を率いて上杉氏征伐に出征し、同日の夕刻には伏見城に入った。
sen.e: On June 16, Ieyasu started going to conquer the Uesugi clan, leading his military forces, from Kyobashi-guchi of Osaka-jo Castle, and entered Fushimi Castle in the evening of the same day.

sen.j: ところが6月23日に浜松、6月24日に島田市、6月25日に駿府、6月26日に三島市、6月27日に小田原市、6月28日に藤沢市、6月29日に鎌倉市、7月1日に金沢区、7月2日に江戸という、遅々たる進軍を行っている。

sen.j: 実際、7月に三成は大谷吉継とともに挙兵すると、家康によって占領されていた大阪城・西の丸を奪い返した。
sen.e: Actually, in July, Mitsunari, together with Yoshitsugu Otani, started moving his forces and took back Nishinomaru (the castle compound to the west of the main compound) of Osaka-jo Castle.

sen.e: Then Mitsunari persuaded the bugyo officers, including Nagamori MASHITA and Masaie NAGATSUKA, to support his side, established Terumoto MORI as the supreme commander, and sent to daimyo a paper for impeaching Ieyasu.

sen.j: 三成が挙兵すると、家康古参の重臣・鳥居元忠が守る伏見城が4万人の軍勢で攻められ、元忠は戦死し伏見城は落城した（伏見城の戦い）。
sen.e: After starting moving his forces, Mitsunari attacked Fushimi-jo Castle, guarded by Mototada TORII, a longtime senior vassal to Ieyasu, with a forces of 40,000 soldiers, and in the fight, Mototada was killed and Fushimi-jo Castle came under Mitsunari (the Battle of Fushimi-jo Castle).

sen.j: さらに三成らは伊勢国、美濃国方面に侵攻した。

sen.j: 家康は下野国・小山城の陣において、伏見城の元忠が発した使者の報告により、三成の挙兵を知った。

sen.j: 家康は、上杉氏征伐に従軍していた諸大名の大半を集め、「秀頼公に害を成す君側の奸臣・三成を討つため」として、上方に反転すると告げた。
sen.e: Gathering most of the daimyo who had been engaged in the fighting to defeat the Uesugi clan, Ieyasu declared that he would change the direction of their movements of the forces, saying that "We should defeat Mitsunari who is a cunning retainer of the Imperial court and does ill to Lord Hideyori."

sen.j: これに対し、福島正則ら三成に反感を持つ武断派の大名らは家康に味方すると告げ、ここに家康の関ヶ原の戦い東軍が結成された（小山評定）。
sen.e: For this, Budan-ha daimyo, including Masanori FUKUSHIMA, who had antipathy against Mitsunari, announced that they would support Ieyasu, and here, Ieyasu's eastern military group forces in the Battle of Sekigahara was formed (Oyama meeting).

sen.j: 東軍は、家康の徳川直属軍と福島正則らの軍勢、合わせて10万人ほどで編成されていた。
sen.e: The eastern military group forces were composed of around 100,000 soldiers, combining Tokugawa's direct forces, and those of Masanori FUKUSHIMA and others.

sen.e: Of them, a troop led by Hidetada TOKUGAWA took the Nakasen-do road from Utsunomiya, while the other forces led by Ieyasu progressed towards Osaka and Kyoto along the Tokai-do road.

sen.j: 他に天正19年（1591年）、家康が相模国の寺社に出した朱印状にも「大納言源朝臣家康」と記された書判もあり、これらのことから笠谷らは「豊臣政権下で家康は既に源氏の公称を許されていた」と述べている。
sen.e: In addition, Ieyasu signed "Dainagon MINAMOTO no Ieyasu" on the shuinjo (vermillion seal letters) issued to shrines and temples in Sagami Province in 1591, and based on these facts, Kasaya and others described that "Ieyasu was permitted to use the name of Minamoto even in the Toyotomi government."

sen.e: On March 21, Ieyasu was officially appointed to shogun at Nijo-jo Castle, and on March 25, he visited the Imperial court and expressed his gratitude for having been appointed to shogun.

sen.j: 豊臣政権の五大老であった家康が、秀吉の死から4年半で武家の棟梁としての地位を手に入れ、名実ともに豊臣氏を上回る地位を確立した。
sen.e: Ieyasu, who had been one of the Go-tairo officers in the Toyotomi government, took the position of the head of samurai in four and a half years after Hideyoshi's death, and established the position that surpassed the Toyotomi clan both in name and reality.

sen.j: 幕府開府に当たって武家諸法度や禁中並公家諸法度の制定、各制度の整備を行い、武家の統制及び朝廷の掌握に向けた法度を定めた。
sen.e: In starting the bakufu, he established laws and regulations to control samurai and the Imperial court, through the introduction of various systems, including the specifications of Buke shohatto (laws for the military families) and of Kinchu narabini kuge shohatto (a set of regulations that were applied to the emperor and the Kyoto nobles).

sen.e: His gaining control of the Imperial court meant that the Toyotomi clan would lose the means of regaining the clan's former power, and therefore, was important for the stabilization of his government after the nation was unified.

sen.e: On April 16 (in the old calendar), 1605, Ieyasu resigned from the shogun post and made the Imperial court appoint Hidetada TOKUNAGA, his third son, to shogun, showing over the nation that "the shogun post should be inherited by the Tokugawa family."

sen.j: 諸寺仏閣の統制を豊臣氏に任せようとしていた兆候もある。
sen.e: There was a sign that he tried to entrust control of temples with the Toyotomi family.

sen.j: また、（秀吉の遺言を受け）孫娘・千姫を秀頼に嫁がせてもいる。
sen.e: Furthermore, he made his granddaughter, Senhime, marry Hideyori (following Hideyoshi's will).

sen.j: しかし、豊臣氏の人々は政権を奪われたことにより次第に家康を警戒するようになっていった。
sen.e: However, because the government was taken over by Ieyasu, people in the Toyotomi clan began gradually becoming cautious about what Ieyasu did.

sen.j: さらに豊臣氏は、徳川氏との決戦に備え、多くの浪人を雇い入れていたが、その多くは関ヶ原の戦いの敗残兵で家康に恨みを持つ者たちであった。
sen.e: In addition, the Toyotomi clan employed many ronin (master-less samurai) for preparing a final war with the Tokugawa clan, and many of them were soldiers of the troops defeated in the Battle of Sekigahara and bore a grudge against Ieyasu.

sen.j: そのような中、慶長16年（1611年）に加藤清正、堀尾吉晴、浅野長政、慶長18年（1613年）には浅野幸長、池田輝政など、豊臣恩顧の有力大名が次々と死去した。
sen.e: Meanwhile, many powerful daimyo under an obligation to the Toyotomi family died one after another: For example, Kiyomasa KATO, Yoshiharu HORIO, and Nagamasa ASANO died in 1611, and Nagamasa ASANO, and Terumasa IKEDA in 1613.

sen.j: そのため、次第に豊臣氏は孤立を深めていった（あまりにも豊臣恩顧の大名の死が相次いだため、家康による毒殺説もある）。
sen.e: Therefore, the Toyotomi clan became isolated gradually (because so many daimyo under an obligation to the Toyotomi family died one after another, there is a theory as well that Ieyasu poisoned them).

sen.j: そして慶長19年（1614年）の方広寺鐘銘事件をきっかけとして、家康は豊臣氏を完全に屈服させることを決意し、それを拒んだ場合は滅亡させるべく策動を開始した。
sen.e: Then, taking the opportunity of the incident of the Hoko-ji Temple bell, Ieyasu made up his mind to make the Toyotomi clan subjugated completely, and started the maneuvers to ruin the clan otherwise.

tit.e: The incident of the Hoko-ji Temple bell

sen.j: 豊臣氏は家康の勧めで慶長19年（1614年）4月に方広寺を再建しており、8月3日に大仏殿の開眼供養を行なうことにした。
sen.e: In April (in the old calendar) of 1614, the Toyotomi family reconstructed Hoko-ji Temple according to Ieyasu's recommendation, and it was scheduled to hold a ceremony to consecrate a newly made Buddhist statue by inserting the eyes (thereby investing it with soul) in the Daibutsu-den (the Great Buddha hall).

In April (in the old calendar) of 1614, the Toyotomi family reconstructed Hoko-ji Temple according to Ieyasu's recommendation, and it was scheduled to hold a ceremony to consecrate a newly made Buddhist statue by inserting the eyes (thereby investing it with soul) in the Daibutsu-den (the Great Buddha hall) on August 3.

sen.j: ところが家康は、方広寺の梵鐘の銘文中に不吉な語があると供養を差し止めた。
sen.e: However, Ieyasu stopped holding the ceremony, saying that the inscription on the bonsho (temple bell) included ominous terms.

sen.j: 問題とされたのは「国家安康」・「君臣豊楽・子孫殷昌」・「右僕射源朝臣」の部分であった。
sen.e: He made the following the problematic terms: "国家安康," "君臣豊楽・子孫殷昌," and "右僕射源朝臣."
He made the following the problematic terms: "国家安康," "君臣豊楽・子孫殷昌," and "右僕射源朝臣."

sen.j: 「国家安康」を「家康の名を分断して呪詛する言葉」とし、「君臣豊楽・子孫殷昌」を豊臣氏を君として子孫の殷昌を楽しむとした。
sen.e: He said that, with the characters of 家 and 康 in his name (家康: Ieyasu) included divided in it, the phrase of "国家安康"was ominous, and that the phrase of 君臣豊楽・子孫殷昌 meant that descendants would be prosperous with the Toyotomi family as the lord.

He said that, with the characters of 家 and 康 in his name (家康: Ieyasu) included divided in it, the phrase of "国家安康"was ominous, and that the phrase of 君臣豊楽・子孫殷昌 meant that descendants would be prosperous with the Toyotomi family as the lord.

He said that, with the characters of 家 and 康 in his name (家康: Ieyasu) included divided in it, the phrase of '国家安康'was ominous, and that the phrase of 君臣豊楽・子孫殷昌 meant that descendants would be prosperous with the Toyotomi family as the lord.

sen.j: 更に「右僕射源朝臣」については、「家康を射るという言葉だ」と非難したのである。
sen.e: In addition, he accused that the phrase of "右僕射源朝臣" meant shooting Ieyasu.
In addition, he said that the phrase of "右僕射源朝臣" meant shooting Ieyasu.

sen.j: こちらは完全な言いがかりであり、「右僕射源朝臣」の本来の意味は、右僕射（右大臣の唐名）源家康という意味である。
sen.e: This last one was a complete false charge, and the original meaning of "右僕射源朝臣" was 右僕射 (Tang's expression for minister of the right) and 源家康 (MINAMOTO no Ieyasu).

sen.j: さらに8月18日、京都五山の長老たちに鐘銘の解釈を行わせた。
sen.e: Furthermore, on August 18, he made senior priests at Kyoto-Gozan (five big temples in Kyoto) interpret the inscription on the temple bell.

sen.j: その結果、五山の僧侶たちは家康の影響力を恐れて、「みなこの銘中に国家安康の一句、御名を犯す事尤不敬とすべし。」（徳川実紀）と返答したという。
sen.e: For this, the priests is said to have answered, fearing the influential power of Ieyasu, that the phrase of 国家安康 in the inscription considered being extremely impious, because it damaged the name of Ieyasu (according to Tokugawa Jikki (a collection of official records of the Edo bakufu).

sen.j: これに対して豊臣氏は家老・片桐且元と鐘銘を作成した文英清韓を駿府に派遣し、家康に弁明を試みた。
sen.e: For this, the Toyotomi family sent Katsumoto KATAGIRI, a Karo (top retainer) and Seikan BUNEI, who made the inscription, to Sunpu, to offer an explanation for the situation.

sen.j: ところが、家康は会見すら拒否し、逆に清韓を拘束し、且元を大坂へ返した。
sen.e: However, Ieyasu refused even to see them, took Seikan into custody and sent Katsumoto back to Osaka.
However, Ieyasu refused even to see them, took Seikan into custody and sent Katsumoto back to Osaka.

sen.j: 且元は、秀頼の大坂城退去などを提案し妥協を図ったが、豊臣氏は拒否。
sen.e: Katsumoto proposed Hideyori to leave Osaka-jo Castle as a compromise measure, but the Toyotomi family turned down the proposal.

sen.j: そして、豊臣氏が9月26日に且元を家康と内通しているとして追放した。
sen.e: Then on September 26, the Toyotomi family exiled Katsumoto saying that he had communicated with Ieyasu secretly.

sen.j: すると、家康は豊臣氏が浪人を集めて軍備を増強していることを理由に、豊臣氏に宣戦布告したのである。
sen.e: Taking this opportunity, Ieyasu declared a war with the Toyotomi clan for the reason that the Toyotomi clan increased forces by recruiting ronin (master-less samurai).

sen.j: この事件は、豊臣氏攻撃の口実とするため、家康が崇伝,林羅山らと画策して問題化させたものであるとの考え方が一般的であった。
sen.e: It has been considered generally that this incident was conceived and made a problem by Ieyasu, together with Suden and Razan HAYASHI, to give a pretext for attacking the Toyotomi clan.

sen.j: しかし、清韓自身が家康の諱を「かくし題」とした意識的な撰文であると弁明しており、上記のとおり、五山の僧の答申はいずれも諱を避けなかったことについて問題視している。
sen.e: However, Seikan himself explained that the imina (personal name) of 家康 was inserted into the inscription intentionally, and each priest at Kyoto-Gozan replied that it was a problem not to have avoided including the imina

sen.j: 当時、基本的に諱で呼ぶ事が出来るのは両親、主君そして敵であり、通常は名字＋官職名もしくは通名等で呼んだ。
sen.e: At that time, the persons who could use imina in calling a man basically were the man's parents, the man's master or the man's enemies, and in such a situation, the family name with the his governmental post name added, or the man's common name was usually used.

sen.j: 諱で呼ぶことは非常に無礼なことであった。
sen.e: It was quite rude to call a man with his or her imina.

sen.j: このような事を考えると、家康側が全面的にこじつけたものではなく、豊臣側の軽率な行為が付け入る隙を与えたという性格の方が強い。
sen.e: When taking these into consideration, it is considered that the allegation on Ieyasu's side was not a farfetched one, but rather that a careless act on the Toyotomi side allowed the Ieyasu side a chance to take advantage.

sen.j: 慶長19年（1614年）11月15日、家康は二条城を発して大坂城攻めの途についた。
sen.e: On November 15 (in the old calendar), 1614, Ieyasu left Nijo-jo Castle for attacking Osaka-jo Castle.

sen.j: そして20万人からなる大軍で大坂城を完全包囲させた。
sen.e: Then his large forces of 200,000 soldiers completely enclosed Osaka-jo Castle.

sen.j: しかしながら、力攻めはせず、大坂城外にある砦などを攻めるという局地戦を行うにとどめた。
sen.e: However, he did not attack directly with forces, but limited his activities to local fights, for example, attacks on forts outside Osaka-jo Castle.

sen.j: 徳川軍は木津川口の戦い (1614年)・今福の戦い・鴫野の戦い・博労淵の戦いなどの局地戦で勝利を重ねたが、真田丸の戦いでは、真田信繁（幸村）の前に大敗を喫した。
sen.e: The Tokugawa forces continued winning such local fights as the Battle of Kitsugawa-guchi, the Battle of Imafuku, the Battle of Kamono, and the Battle of Bakurobuchi, but were defeated seriously by Nobushige (Yukimura) SANADA in the fight at the Sanada-maru (Sanada barbican).

sen.j: とはいえ戦局を揺るがすほどの敗戦ではなく、徳川軍は新たな作戦を始動した。
sen.e: However, the defeat was not serious enough to change the war situation largely, and the Tokugawa forces started taking a new strategy.

sen.j: 午後8時、午前0時、午前4時に一斉に勝ち鬨をあげさせ、さらに午後10時、午前2時、午前6時に大砲（石火矢・大筒）を放たせて城兵、特に戦慣れしていない淀殿らを脅そうとした。
sen.e: To threaten the soldiers in the castle and Yodo-do in particular, who was unfamiliar with wars, he made his soldiers give a shout of victory at 8 PM, 0 AM, and 4 AM, and made cannons (ishibiya (guns with stones as bullets), and artillery) fired at 10 PM, 2 AM, and 6 AM.

sen.j: この砲撃作戦は成功した。

sen.j: 落城の恐怖に怯えた淀殿は和睦することを申し出て、家康もそれを了承した。
sen.e: Fearing that the castle might be destroyed, Yodo-dono proposed to make peace with Ieyasu, and Ieyasu agreed with it as well.

sen.j: 和議の条件は、大坂城の外堀の埋め立てと二の丸、三の丸の破壊であった。
sen.e: The conditions for making the peace were to fill the outer moats of the Osaka-jo Castle, and to destroy Nino-maru (the second compound of the castle) and Sanno-maru (the third compound of the castle).
