sen.j: しかしながら、家康は本多正純に命じて条件になかった内堀までも埋め立てさせた。
sen.e: However, Ieyasu ordered Masazumi HONDA to fill the inner moats as well, which was not included in the conditions.

sen.j: そのため、慶長20年（1615年）1月中旬までに、大坂城は本丸だけを残す無防備な裸城となった。
sen.e: Therefore, by the middle of January, 1615, the Osaka-jo Castle had become a naked castle with only Honmaru (the keep of the castle)

sen.j: 和睦の条件になかった内堀まで埋め立てられたため、豊臣氏はこれを掘り返そうとした。
sen.e: Because the inner moats had been filled, ignoring the conditions for peace, the Toyotomi side tried to dig them again.

sen.j: ところが家康は、それを「豊臣氏が戦準備を進めている」という大義名分にし、大坂城内の浪人の追放と豊臣氏の移封を要求。
sen.e: However, on the pretext that the act constituted "Toyotomi's preparations for a war," Ieyasu demanded to exile ronin and to change the territory of the Toyotomi family.

sen.j: 更に徳川義直の婚儀のためと称して上洛するのに合わせ、またも近畿方面に大軍を送り込み、豊臣氏に要求が拒否されるや侵攻を開始した。
sen.e: Furthermore, when he was going to Kyoto saying that it was for the marriage of Yoshinao TOKUGAWA, he sent large forces to the Kinki region, and started attacking the Toyotomi clan soon after his demands were turned down.

sen.j: これに対して豊臣氏は、大坂城からの出撃策をとったが兵力で圧倒的に不利であり、塙直之、後藤基次、木村重成、薄田兼相ら勇将を相次いで失ってしまう。
sen.e: For this, the Toyotomi clan made a sortie from Osaka-jo Castle, but being overwhelmingly disadvantageous in the number of soldiers, lost many brave military commanders, including Naoyuki BAN, Mototsugu GOTO, Shigenari KIMURA, and Kanesuke SUSUKIDA, one after another.

sen.j: 徳川軍は大軍ゆえの油断や連携の拙さ、真田信繁や毛利勝永らの奮闘もあって、一時は徳川家康の馬印が倒れ、家康自身も自決を覚悟するほどの危機にも見舞われた。
sen.e: Due to strenuous efforts of Nobushige SANADA and of Katsunaga MORI as well as inattention and bad cooperation because among big forces, the Tokugawa forces met such a dangerous situation for a while that the Uma-jirushi (massive flags used in Japan to identify a daimyo or equally important military commander on the field of battle) of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA fell and Ieyasu himself made his mind to kill himself.

sen.j: しかしながら、やがて態勢を立て直した徳川軍により信繁・勝永らも戦死し、遂に大坂城は落城した。
sen.e: However, meanwhile, Nobushige and Katsunaga were killed in fights by the Tokugawa forces that had rebuilt the fighting system, and Osaka-jo Castle was taken by Ieyasu.

sen.j: 5月8日、豊臣秀頼と淀殿、そしてその側近らは自害し、ここに豊臣氏は滅亡した。
sen.e: On May 8, Hideyori TOYOTOMI and Yodo-dono, and their close associates killed themselves, and the Toyotomi clan was ruined.

sen.j: 「家康は秀頼の自害直前に保護しようとしたが間に合わず泣き伏したという」という説もある。
sen.e: There is also the theory that "Ieyasu tried to take Hideyori into his custody before he killed himself, but having been too late, threw himself down in tears."

sen.j: その後大坂城は完全に埋め立てられ、その上に徳川氏によって新たな大坂城が再建された。
sen.e: After that, the Osaka-jo Castle was completely destroyed and the land was made flat, on which a new Osaka-jo Castle was built by the Tokugawa clan.

sen.j: 秀吉へ死後授けられた豊国大明神の神号が廃され、豊國神社 (大阪市)と秀吉の廟であった豊国廟が閉鎖・放置されている。
sen.e: The shingo (the title of god) of Hokoku Daimyojin (Great Luminous Deity of Our Bountiful Country), given to Hideyoshi posthumously, was abolished, and Hokoku-jinja Shrine (in Osaka City) and Toyokuni-byo (the mausoleum for Hideyoshi) were closed and left unattended.

sen.j: 明治維新の後に豊国大明神号は復活し、東照宮にも信長や秀吉が祀られるようになっている。
sen.e: After the Meiji restoration, the shingo of Hokoku Daimyojin was restored, and Nobunaga and Hideyoshi became to be enshrined in Tosho-gu Shrine as well.

sen.j: 元和 (日本)元年（1615年）、家康は禁中並公家諸法度を制定して、朝幕関係の構築と徳川将軍家と天皇家の君臣の別を明らかにした。
sen.e: In 1615, Ieyasu established Kinchu narabini kuge shohatto (a set of regulations that applied to the emperor and the Kyoto nobles) to establish relationships between the bakufu and the Imperial court, and to clarify differences between the lord-retainer relationships in the Tokugawa shogun family and those in the emperorr family.

sen.j: また、諸大名統制のために武家諸法度・一国一城令が制定された。
sen.e: Furthermore, Buke shohatto (laws for the military families) and Ikkoku Ichijo Rei (the law for one castle per province) were established to control daimyo.

sen.j: こうして、徳川氏による日本全域の支配を実現し、徳川氏264年の天下を安泰なものとした。
sen.e: In this way, Ieyasu achieved control of the entire areas of Japan by the Tokugawa clan, and enabled the stable control of the nation by the Tokugawa clan for 264 years

sen.j: 元和2年（1616年）1月、鷹狩に出た先で倒れた。

sen.j: 3月21日に朝廷から太政大臣の位を贈られた。
sen.e: On March 21, he was conferred to the rank of Daijo-daijin (Grand Minister) by the Imperial court.

sen.j: 4月17日 (旧暦)の巳（午前10時ごろ）に駿府城において死去した。
sen.e: On April 17 (around 10 AM), he died in Sunpu-jo Castle.

sen.j: 享年75。
sen.e: He was at the age of 75, when his life length was counted by the number of years in which he lived.
He was in his 75th year.
He died at the age of 75.

sen.j: 死因は、鯛の天ぷらによる食中毒説が有力であった。
sen.e: An intoxication from fried sea bream was the most plausible theory for the cause of the death.
Poisoning from fried sea bream was the most plausible cause of death.
Poisoning from fried sea bream was the most plausible cause of death.

sen.j: しかし、家康が鯛の天ぷらを食べたのは1月21日_(旧暦)の夕食であり、亡くなったのは4月17日で（いずれも旧暦）であった。
sen.e: However, it was January 21 (in the old calendar) when Ieyasu ate fried sea bream for the evening meal, and it was on April 17 (in the old calendar) that he died.

sen.e: If the cause was the intoxication of the food, too many days passed between them.

sen.j: 諸症状から見て胃癌か梅毒と考えられている。

sen.j: なお、家康が問題の天ぷらを食べたのは田中城（現静岡県藤枝市田中）であった。
sen.e: By the way, it was at Tanaka-jo Castle (in present Tanaka, Fujieda City, Shizuoka Prefecture) that he ate the problematic fried food.

sen.j: 辞世の句として『東照宮御実記』に以下の二首を詠んだと伝わっている。
sen.e: It is recorded in "Toshogu-gojikki" that the following two poems were the last ones he composed before his death.

sen.j: 「嬉やと 再び覚めて 一眠り 浮世の夢は 暁の空」
sen.e: "Being happy, I awaked again and will sleep for while; The worldly dream is the sky at dawn."
sen.cmt: この句の訳：解釈が正しいかは不明です。

sen.j: 「先にゆき 跡に残るも 同じ事 つれて行ぬを 別とぞ思ふ」
sen.e: "Either of going first or of being left behind is the same; I consider that it is farewell because I cannot go with you."

sen.j: 江戸城内においては天ぷらを料理することは禁止されていた。
sen.e: It was prohibited to cook fried foods within Edo-jo Castle.

sen.j: これは家康の死因が天ぷらによる食中毒であるためという説明がなされる場合もある。
sen.e: It is sometimes explained that the reason was because Ieyasu died from an intoxication of fried food.

sen.j: しかしながら、実際には、大奥の侍女のひとりが天ぷらを料理していて、火事を出しかけたために禁止されたというのが事実である。
sen.e: However, the fact was that the cooking was prohibited because a fire became likely to be caused when a female servant in O-koku (the inner halls of Edo Castle where the wife of the Shogun and her servants reside) was cooking fried foods.

sen.j: 同日付で息子徳川秀忠も侍従に任官しているが、これは豊臣秀忠名義となっている。

sen.j: 同様に、同年12月28日付の「左近衛大将左馬寮御監両官職兼帯」の宣旨、慶長元年5月8日付の正二位内大臣の昇叙転任の宣旨についても豊臣家康の名義と考えられる。
sen.e: In the similar way, it is considered that the following two decrees were also issued with the name of Ieyasu TOYOTOMI: the one of "should assume both posts of Sakone no daisho (Major Captain of the Left Division of Inner Palace Guards) and Samaryo gogen (Inspector of the Samaryo, Left Division of Bureau of Horses)," dated on May 28, the same year, and the one for promoting him to Shonii (Senior Second Rank) and for changing the post to Naidaijin (Inner Minister), dated December 28 (in the old calendar), 1596.

sen.j: 現在、日光東照宮所蔵の徳川家康の任官叙位の宣旨は、徳川家康の任官叙位の宣旨が遺失したため（徳川実紀正保2年5月8日条）、正保2年（1645年）、征夷大将軍・徳川家光の要請により、朝廷に対して再発行の手続きによる文書として伝わっており、再発行の段階で豊臣から源に変更した可能性がある。
sen.e: The decrees having been issued for awarding ranks and for appointing posts to Ieyasu TOKUGAWA were lost (recorded in the article on May 8 (in the old calendar), 1645, of Tokugawa Jikki), and those that are now stored in Tosho-gu Shrine are the documents that were obtained through requesting the Imperial court to re-issue them, and there is a possibility that the name of Toyotomi was changed to Minamoto when re-issuing them.

sen.j: 家康の遺言により、始めは駿府の南東の久能山（現久能山東照宮）に葬られ、一周忌を経て江戸城の真北に在る日光市の東照社に改葬された。
sen.e: According to Ieyasu's will, his body was buried in Kuno-san Mountain in the southeast of Sunpu (present Kuno-san Tosho-gu Shrine) initially, but after the first anniversary of his death, was re-buried in Tosho-sha Shrine in Nikko City in the precise north of Edo-jo Castle.

According to Ieyasu's will, his body was buried in Kuno-san Mountain in the southeast of Sunpu (present Kuno-san Tosho-gu Shrine) initially, but after the first anniversary of his death, was re-buried in Tosho-sha Shrine in Nikko City due north of Edo-jo Castle.

According to Ieyasu's will, his body was buried in Mt. Kuno in the southeast of Sunpu (present Tosho-gu Shrine on Mt. Kuno) initially, but after the first anniversary of his death, was re-buried in Tosho-sha Shrine in Nikko City due north of Edo-jo Castle.

sen.j: 神号は側近の天海と崇伝の間で、権現と明神の何れとするかが争われたが天海が勝ち、山王一実神道に則って薬師如来を本地とする権現とされた。
sen.e: Tenkai and Suden contested whether his shingo should be Gongen (incarnation) or Myojin (a gracious deity), and with Tenkai having won, Ieyasu was made the Gongen (incarnation) of Yakushinyorai (Bhaisajyaguru, Buddha able to cure all ills) based on Sanno-ichijitsu Shinto.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処山王神道山王一実神道： ウェッブ上での表現に合わせ”山王一実神道”に変更した上で訳してあります。
sen.e: Tenkai and Suden contested whether his shingo should be Gongen (incarnation) or Myojin (a gracious deity), and with Tenkai having won, Ieyasu was made the Gongen (incarnation) of Yakushinyorai (Bhaisajyaguru, Buddha able to cure all ills) based on Sanno-ichijitsu Shinto.

The close retainers, Tenkai and Suden, contested whether his shingo should be Gongen (incarnation) or Myojin (a gracious deity), and with Tenkai having won, Ieyasu was made the Gongen (incarnation) of Yakushinyorai (Bhaisajyaguru, Buddha able to cure all ills) based on Sanno-ichijitsu Shinto.

sen.j: それから、元和3年（1617年）2月21日に東照大権現の神号、3月9日に神階正一位が贈られる。
sen.e: Then the singo of Tosho-Daigongen was awarded on February 21 (in the old calendar), 1617, and the god rank of Shoichii (Senior First Rank) on March 9.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Then the shingo of Tosho-Daigongen was awarded on February 21 (in the old calendar), 1617, and the god rank of Shoichii (Senior First Rank) on March 9.
Then the shingo of Tosho-Daigongen was awarded on February 21 (in the old calendar), 1617, and the god rank of Shoichii (Senior First Rank) on March 9.

sen.j: 東照社は正保2年（1645年）11月3日に宮号宣下があり、日光東照宮となった。
sen.e: The decree of permitting use of the character of gu (宮) was issued for Tosho-sha (社), and the shrine became named Nikko Tosho-gu Shrine.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The decree permitting use of the character of gu (宮) was issued for Tosho-sha (社), and the shrine became named Nikko Tosho-gu Shrine.
The decree permitting use of the character of gu (宮) was issued for Tosho-sha (社) on November 3 (in the old calendar), 1645, and the shrine became named Nikko Tosho-gu Shrine.

sen.j: さらに東照宮に正一位の神階が贈られた。
sen.e: In addition, the god rank of Shoichii was also awarded to Tosho-gu Shrine.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In addition, the god rank of Shoichii was also awarded to Tosho-gu Shrine.
In addition, the god rank of Shoichii was also awarded to Tosho-gu Shrine.

sen.j: 家康は江戸幕府の始祖として東照神君、権現様とも呼ばれ江戸時代を通して崇拝された。
sen.e: As the founder of the Edo bakufu, Ieyasu was sometimes called Tosho-sinkun or Gongen-sama, and was worshiped throughout the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: As the founder of the Edo bakufu, Ieyasu was sometimes called Tosho-shinkun or Gongen-sama, and was worshiped throughout the Edo period.
As the founder of the Edo bakufu, Ieyasu was sometimes called Tosho-shinkun or Gongen-sama, and was worshiped throughout the Edo period.

sen.j: 現在も日光東照宮の奥社を墓所としている。
sen.e: Even today, his graveyard is in the inner shrine of Nikko Tosho-gu Shrine.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Even today, his graveyard is in the inner shrine of Nikko Tosho-gu Shrine.
Even today, his graveyard is in the inner shrine of Nikko Tosho-gu Shrine.

sen.j: 他の霊廟としては松平氏の菩提寺である愛知県岡崎市の大樹寺、高野山にある徳川氏霊台の安国院殿霊廟がある。
sen.e: Daiju-ji Temple, the Matsudaira clan's family temple located in Okazaki City, Aichi Prefecture, and Ankokuin-reibyo in Koya-san Mountain, are his mausoleums as well.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Daiju-ji Temple, the Matsudaira clan's family temple located in Okazaki City, Aichi Prefecture, and Ankokuin-reibyo in Koya-san Mountain, are his mausoleums as well.
Daiju-ji Temple, the Matsudaira clan's family temple located in Okazaki City, Aichi Prefecture, and Ankokuin-reibyo on Mt. Koya, are his mausoleums as well.

sen.j: また各地の東照宮に祀られている。
sen.e: In addition, he is enshrined in the Tosho-gu shrines throughout Japan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In addition, he is enshrined in the Tosho-gu shrines throughout Japan.
In addition, he is enshrined in the Tosho-gu shrines throughout Japan.

sen.j: なお、徳川将軍15人中寛永寺か増上寺のどちらにも墓所がないのは家康以外には徳川家光と徳川慶喜がいる。
sen.e: By the way, of 15 Tokugawa shogun, Iemitsu TOKUGAWA and Kanei-ji Temple in addition to Ieyasu are not buried in Kanei-ji Temple nor Zojo-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 徳川幕府徳川将軍一覧中： ウェッブ上での表現”徳川将軍15人中"に置き換えた上で、訳してあります。
sen.e: By the way, of 15 Tokugawa shogun, Iemitsu TOKUGAWA and Ieyasu are not buried in Kanei-ji Temple nor Zojo-ji Temple.
By the way, of 15 Tokugawa shogun, Iemitsu TOKUGAWA and Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA in addition to Ieyasu are not buried in Kanei-ji Temple nor Zojo-ji Temple.

sen.j: その戦上手は「海道一の弓取」と称され、江戸時代には家康は「神君家康公」と呼ばれた。
sen.e: For being good at fighting, he was called "being the best in handling a bow along the Tokai-do road," and was called "God lord Ieyasu" in the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: For being good at fighting, he was called "the best in handling a bow along the Tokai-do road," and was called "God lord Ieyasu" in the Edo period.
For being good at fighting, he was called 'the best in handling a bow along the Tokai-do road,' and was called 'God lord Ieyasu' in the Edo period.

sen.j: 公然と彼を批判対象とした評論を発表すれば処罰の対象となった。
sen.e: When a person criticized him publicly, he was punished.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: When a person criticized him publicly, he was punished.
When a person criticized him publicly, he was punished.

sen.j: 逆に明治から太平洋戦争後までは、朝廷を抑圧した「奸臣」として、賞賛することは慮られるようになった。
sen.e: On the contrary, in the era from the Meiji period to the end of the Pacific War, it became to be hesitated to praise him, for the reason that he was a "cunning retainer" who repressed the Imperial court.
On the contrary, in the era from the Meiji period to the end of the Pacific War, people hesitated to praise him, for the reason that he was a "cunning retainer" who repressed the Imperial court.

sen.j: 戦後になって比較的自由な家康批評が行われるようになった。
sen.e: After the war, evaluations of Ieyasu have become to be made freely
sen.cmt: 第二次世界大戦後： ウェッブ上の表現に合わせ、これらの語句を削除した上で訳してあります。
sen.e: After the war, evaluations of Ieyasu have been made freely.
After the war, evaluations of Ieyasu have been made freely.

tit.j: 江戸幕府の支配に関して
tit.e: Concerning the control of the Edo bakufu
Concerning the control of the Edo bakufu
Concerning the control of the Edo bakufu

sen.j: 家康が礎を築いた徳川将軍家を頂点とする江戸幕府の支配体系は極めて完成度の高いものである。
sen.e: The control system of the Edo bakufu that Ieyasu established, with the Tokugawa shogun family at its pinnacle, was an extremely complete one.
The control system of the Edo bakufu that Ieyasu established, with the Tokugawa shogun family at its pinnacle, was an extremely complete one.
The control system of the Edo bakufu that Ieyasu established, with the Tokugawa shogun family at its pinnacle, was an extremely complete one.

sen.j: 江戸幕府は京都、大坂、堺など全国の幕府直轄主要都市（天領）を含め約400万石、旗本知行地を含めれば全国の総石高の1/3に相当する約700万石を独占管理（親藩・譜代大名領を加えればさらに増加する）した。
sen.e: The Edo bakufu exclusively controlled the areas producing an approx. 4 million koku of rice crop, including major cities controlled directly by the bakufu (called Tenryo), such as Kyoto, Osaka, and Sakai, and approx. 7 million koku when the territories of Hatamoto (direct retainers of the Tokugawa family) were included additionally, one-third of the total amount of rice crop in the nation (the amount was much more when the territories of Shinpan (whose lords were a relative of the shogun family) and Fudai-daimyo (the daimyo whose families were retainers from before the Battle of Sekigahara) were added as well.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Edo bakufu exclusively controlled an area producing approx. 4 million koku of rice, including major cities controlled directly by the bakufu (called Tenryo), such as Kyoto, Osaka, and Sakai, and approx. 7 million koku when the territories of Hatamoto (direct retainers of the Tokugawa family) were included additionally, one-third of the total amount of rice crop in the nation (the amount was much more when the territories of Shinpan (whose lords were a relative of the shogun family) and Fudai-daimyo (the daimyo whose families were retainers from before the Battle of Sekigahara) were added as well.

The Edo bakufu exclusively controlled an area producing approx. 4 million koku of rice, including major cities controlled directly by the bakufu (called Tenryo), such as Kyoto, Osaka, and Sakai, and approx. 7 million koku when the territories of Hatamoto (direct retainers of the Tokugawa family) were included additionally, one-third of the total amount of rice crop in the nation (the amount was much more when the territories of Shinpan (whose lords were a relative of the shogun family) and Fudai-daimyo (the daimyo whose families were retainers from before the Battle of Sekigahara) were added as well.

sen.j: さらには佐渡金山など重要鉱山と貨幣を作る権利も独占して貨幣経済の根幹もおさえるなど、他の大名の追随を許さない圧倒的な権力基盤を持っていた。
sen.e: In addition, the bakufu had overwhelming power outclassing other daimyo, for example, by controlling the basis of monetary economy through the possession of important mines, such as the gold mine on the Sado island, and through the monopoly of the minting right.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In addition, the bakufu had overwhelming power outclassing other daimyo, for example, by controlling the basis of monetary economy through the possession of important mines, such as the gold mine on Sado island, and through the monopoly of the minting right.

In addition, the bakufu had overwhelming power outclassing other daimyo, for example, by controlling the basis of monetary economy through the possession of important mines, such as the gold mine on Sado island, and through the monopoly of the minting right.

sen.j: これを背景に全国諸大名、寺社、朝廷、そして天皇家までをもいくつもの法度で取り締まり支配した。
sen.e: With these as backgrounds, the bakufu regulated and controlled even the emperor's family in addition to the daimyo throughout the nation, shrines and temples, and the Imperial court, through various laws and regulations.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: With this background, the bakufu regulated and controlled even the emperor's family in addition to the daimyo throughout the nation, shrines and temples, and the Imperial court, through various laws and regulations.

With this background, the bakufu regulated and controlled even the emperor's family in addition to the daimyo throughout the nation, shrines and temples, and the Imperial court, through various laws and regulations.

sen.j: これに逆らうもの、もしくは幕府に対して危険であると判断されたものには容赦しなかった。
sen.e: When a person acted against the control or was judged to be dangerous for the bakufu, the person was not tolerated.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: When a person acted against the control or was judged to be dangerous for the bakufu, the person was not tolerated.
When a person acted against the control or was judged to be dangerous for the bakufu, the person was not tolerated.

sen.j: そのため江戸幕府の初期はいくつもの大名が改易（取り潰し）の憂き目にあっている。
sen.e: Therefore, in the early Edo bakufu period, many daimyo were deprived of their territories.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, in the early Edo bakufu period, many daimyo were deprived of their territories.
Therefore, in the early Edo bakufu period, many daimyo were deprived of their territories.

sen.j: これは朝廷や天皇家でさえも例外ではなく、紫衣事件などはその象徴的事件であった。
sen.e: Even the Imperial court and the emperor's family were no exceptionn, and the Shie Incident (the great conflict between the shogunate and the Imperial Court, concerning priests' robes which were usually purple) was a symbolic one.

Even the Imperial court and the emperor's family were no exception, and the Shie Incident (the great conflict between the shogunate and the Imperial Court, concerning priests' robes which were usually purple) was a symbolic one.

Even the Imperial court and the emperor's family were no exception, and the Shie Incident (the great conflict between the shogunate and the Imperial Court, concerning priests' robes which were usually purple) was a symbolic one.

sen.j: 幕府に従順な大名に対しても参勤交代などで常に財政を圧迫させ幕府に反抗する力を与えることを許さなかった。
sen.e: The bakufu financially oppressed eｖen daimyo obedient to the bakufu, for example, with the Sankin-kotai system (a system under which feudal lords in the Edo period were required to spend every other year in residence in Edo), not to allow them to have the power to resist the bakufu.

The bakufu financially oppressed even daimyo obedient to the bakufu, for example, with the Sankin-kotai system (a system under which feudal lords in the Edo period were required to spend every other year in residence in Edo), not to allow them to have the power to resist the bakufu.

The bakufu financially oppressed even daimyo obedient to the bakufu, for example, with the Sankin-kotai system (a system under which feudal lords in the Edo period were required to spend every other year in residence in Edo), not to allow them to have the power to resist the bakufu.

sen.j: このように圧倒的な権力基盤を背景にして徳川将軍家を頂点に君臨させ、全国の諸大名・朝廷・天皇家を「生かさず殺さず、逆らえば（もしくはその危険があるならば）潰す」の姿勢で支配したのが家康の築いた江戸幕府であった。
sen.e: It was the Ieyasu-established Edo bakufu that, placing the Tokugawa shogun family at its pinnacle of the reign with its overwhelming power base as the backgrounds, controlled daimyo throughout the nation, the Imperial court, and the emperor's family in the posture of "Do not make them live nor kill them, and abolish a family if it resisted the bakufu (or was dangerous for the bakufu)."
sen.cmt: 次の行の文章を組み入れて訳してあります。
sen.e: It was the Ieyasu-established Edo bakufu that, placing the Tokugawa shogun family at its pinnacle of the reign based on its overwhelming power base, controlled daimyo throughout the nation, the Imperial court, and the emperor's family in the posture of "Do not make them live nor kill them, and abolish a family if it resisted the bakufu (or was dangerous for the bakufu)."

It was the Ieyasu-established Edo bakufu that, placing the Tokugawa shogun family at its pinnacle of the reign based on its overwhelming power base, controlled daimyo throughout the nation, the Imperial court, and the emperor's family in the posture of 'Do not make them live nor kill them, and abolish a family if it resisted the bakufu (or was dangerous for the bakufu).'

sen.j: このように徳川将軍家のみを絶対とする江戸幕府の絶対的な支配体系については「保守的・封建的」との見方もできる。
sen.e: The absolute control system of the Edo bakufu, in which only the Tokugawa shogun family was considered being absolute, could be viewed "conservative and feudal."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The absolute control system of the Edo bakufu, in which only the Tokugawa shogun family was considered to be absolute, could be viewed as "conservative and feudal."
The absolute control system of the Edo bakufu, in which only the Tokugawa shogun family was considered to be absolute, could be viewed as 'conservative and feudal.'

sen.j: 一方、これほどまでの強固な支配体系が確立されたからこそ、戦国時代 (日本)を完全に終結させ、そして江戸幕府が250年以上に及ぶ世界史上類を見ない長期安定政権となったことは否定できない事実である。
sen.e: On the other hand, it is also an undeniable fact that, because such a solid control system had been established, the bakufu government could end the Sengoku period (period of warring states) (in Japan) and could be a long-term stable one that continued for more than 250 years, an unprecedentedly long term in the global history.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: On the other hand, it is also an undeniable fact that, because such a solid control system had been established, the bakufu government could end the Sengoku period (period of warring states) (in Japan) and could be a long-term stable one that continued for more than 250 years, an unprecedentedly long term in global history.

On the other hand, it is also an undeniable fact that, because such a solid control system had been established, the bakufu government could end the Sengoku period (period of warring states) (in Japan) and could be a long-term stable one that continued for more than 250 years, an unprecedentedly long term in global history.

sen.j: そのため、この江戸幕府の礎を築き上げた家康の手腕は今なお高く評価されている。
sen.e: Therefore, Ieyasu's competence of having established the base of the Edo bakufu is evaluated highly.
Therefore, Ieyasu's competence of having established the base of the Edo bakufu is evaluated highly.
Therefore, Ieyasu's competence of having established the base of the Edo bakufu is evaluated highly.

sen.j: また、この統治基盤が有ったからこそ、明治新政府へ移行が速やかに進められたとも言われる。
sen.e: Furthermore, it is also said that, just because this control base existed, the transition to the new Meiji government could be made swiftly.
Furthermore, it is also said that, just because this control base existed, the transition to the new Meiji government could be made swiftly.
Furthermore, it is also said that, just because this control base existed, the transition to the new Meiji government could be made swiftly.

sen.j: 後の鎖国政策につながるような閉鎖的外交方針を諸外国との外交基本政策にしたことから、幕末まで海外諸国からの侵略を防げたと評価できる。
sen.e: It can be evaluated that his employment of closed diplomatic policies leading to later national isolation enabled the nation to prevent invasion from various foreign nations towards the end of the bakufu era.

It can be evaluated that his employment of closed diplomatic policies leading to later national isolation enabled the nation to prevent invasion from various foreign nations towards the end of the bakufu era.

It can be evaluated that his employment of closed diplomatic policies leading to later national isolation enabled the nation to prevent invasion from various foreign nations towards the end of the bakufu era.

sen.j: なお、これらの「業績」は家康の死後に、当時の情勢において行われたもので、彼に対する非難としては的を外している。
sen.e: By the way, these "achievements" were accomplished after his death, based on the situation at that time, and were irrelevant as accusations against him.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: By the way, these "achievements" were accomplished after his death, based on the situation at that time, and were irrelevant as accusations against him.
By the way, these 'achievements' were accomplished after his death, based on the situation at that time, and were irrelevant as accusations against him.

sen.j: また明が海禁策をとるなど、当時の世界的な趨勢であるとも言える。
sen.e: In addition, such a policy was taken globally at that era: For example. Ming took the policy of Kaikin-saku (a measure to impose controls on the sea).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In addition, such a policy was taken globally at that era: For example. Ming took the policy of Kaikin-saku (a measure to impose controls on the sea).
In addition, such a policy was taken globally at that era: For example, Ming took the policy of Kaikin-saku (a measure to impose controls on the sea).

sen.j: 徳川将軍家を絶対君主制とする、全国の諸大名をはじめ寺社勢力、朝廷そして天皇家までも実質支配下に置き、さらには外交面でも閉鎖的な徹底した中央集権的封建支配体制を築き上げたことは日本の近代化を遅れさせる一因となったという非難の声もある。
sen.e: There is the accusation as well that his establishment of a completely centralized feudal control system, in which, with the Tokugawa shogun family placed as the absolute monarch, even the emperor family in addition to the Imperial court as well as daimyo, temples and shrines throughout the nation were placed under its control virtually and closed diplomatic policies were taken, was a factor that delayed modernization of Japan.
sen.cmt: ウェッブ上での表現 ”外交面でも閉鎖的な徹底した中央集権的封建支配体制を築き上げたことは日本の近代化を遅れさせる一因となったという非難の声もある”を補った上で訳してあります。
sen.e: There is the accusation as well that his establishment of a completely centralized feudal control system, in which, with the Tokugawa shogun family placed as the absolute monarch, even the emperor family in addition to the Imperial court as well as daimyo, temples and shrines throughout the nation were placed under its control virtually and closed diplomatic policies were taken, was a factor that delayed modernization of Japan.

There is the accusation as well that his establishment of a completely centralized feudal control system, in which, with the Tokugawa shogun family placed as the absolute monarch, even the emperor family in addition to the Imperial court as well as daimyo, temples and shrines throughout the nation were placed under its control virtually and closed diplomatic policies were taken, was a factor that delayed modernization of Japan.

sen.j: また、これに関連して「生かさず殺さず」の姿勢で百姓を支配しようとした事やキリシタンに対する厳しい弾圧への批判も多い。
sen.e: Furthermore, concerning this, there are many criticisms as well for having controlled farmers in the posture of "Do not kill them nor make them live" and for the harsh repression of Christians.
sen.cmt: ウェッブ上での表現 ”「生かさず殺さず」の姿勢で百姓を支配しようとした” と ”批判も多い” を補った上で訳してあります。
sen.e: Furthermore, concerning this, there are many criticisms as well for having controlled farmers in the posture of "Do not kill them nor make them live" and for the harsh repression of Christians.
Furthermore, concerning this, there are many criticisms as well for having controlled farmers in the posture of 'Do not kill them nor make them live' and for the harsh repression of Christians.

sen.j: 家康は信長以上に朝廷をないがしろにしたと言われ、実際彼は朝廷を事実上支配下においていた。
sen.e: Ieyasu is said to have neglected the Imperial court more than Nobunaga, and actually he virtually placed the Imperial court under his control.
sen.cmt: ウェッブ上での表現 ”家康は信長以上に朝廷をないがしろにしたと言われ” を補った上で訳してあります。
sen.e: Ieyasu is said to have neglected the Imperial court more than Nobunaga, and actually he virtually placed the Imperial court under his control.
Ieyasu is said to have neglected the Imperial court more than Nobunaga, and actually he virtually placed the Imperial court under his control.

sen.j: 慶長11年（1606年）には幕府の推挙無しに大名の官位の授与を禁止し、禁中並公家諸法度を制定するなどして朝廷の政治関与を徹底的に排除している。
sen.e: In 1606, he prohibited the Imperial court from awarding official ranks to daimyo without recommendation of the bakufu, and established Kinchu narabini kuge shohatto, to thoroughly remove the political involvement of the Imperial court.

In 1606, he prohibited the Imperial court from awarding official ranks to daimyo without recommendation of the bakufu, and established Kinchu narabini kuge shohatto, to thoroughly remove the political involvement of the Imperial court.

In 1606, he prohibited the Imperial court from awarding official ranks to daimyo without recommendation of the bakufu, and established Kinchu narabini kuge shohatto, to thoroughly remove the political involvement of the Imperial court.

sen.j: 大坂冬の陣の最中である12月17日、朝廷は家康に勅による和睦を斡旋したが、家康はこれを拒否した。

sen.e: After Ieyasu died, his territory was expanded, and Tadatomo OKUBO in the next generation regained the family's former territory of Odawara, with its earning base increased to a 110,000 koku of rice crop as a powerful Fudai daimyo (however, it cannot be denied that there is the view that this was because Tadatomo was a grandson of Ieyasu).

sen.j: これは、家康が謀略に長けていたことを表すものであるが、同時に卑劣な人物であったという印象も与えるものであり、近年の家康に対する評価を大変低くさせている一因となっている。
sen.e: Although having been used for indicating that Ieyasu was good at plotting, this nickname also gives the impression that he was a mean person as well, causing a factor to have degraded recent evaluations of Ieyasu considerably.

sen.j: 家康は常に冷静沈着な知将だったとされているが、短気で神経質な一面も持ち、関ヶ原の序盤戦で東軍が不利だったとき、門奈長三郎という小姓の指物の竿を一刀のもとに切り捨てたという。
sen.e: It is said that Ieyasu was a calm and composed resourceful general, but he had impatient and nervous characters as well: For example, it is said that when the eastern military group forces were placed in an advantageous situation in the initial phase of the Battle of Sekigahara, he cut the sashimono (flagpole) of the pageboy named Chozaburo MONNA.

sen.j: さらに家康は苛立ったり、自分が不利になったりすると、親指の爪を常に噛み、時には皮膚を破って血を流すこともあったという。
sen.e: It is also said that when being irritated or being placed in a disadvantageous situation, he always bit the nail of his thumb, and sometimes bit it so strongly that the skin was broken and blood few from there.
It is also said that when irritated or placed in a disadvantageous situation, he always bit the nail of his thumb, and sometimes bit it so strongly that the skin was broken and it bled.

sen.j: 情を排する冷徹な現実主義者との評価がある一方、三方ヶ原の戦いで家康の身代わりとなって討死した夏目吉信の子が規律違反を犯しても超法規的に赦し、本多忠勝の決死の嘆願で真田昌幸を助命するなど、感情に流されるケースもある。
sen.e: Although he was evaluated as a cool-headed realist, there were also the cases, as described in the followings, in which he got swayed by emotion: When a child of Yoshinobu NATSUME, who had been killed in place of Ieyasu in the Battle of Mikatagahara, violated a rule, Ieyasu pardoned him by a special procedure beyond the law, and Ieyasu also spared Masayuki SANADA's life responding to Tadakatsu HONDA's desperate appeal.

sen.j: 特に苦労を共にしてきた三河時代からの家臣たちとの信頼関係は厚った。
sen.e: In particular, the trust between him and his retainers, who had endured hardships together with him from his Mikawa period, was strong.

sen.j: 三方ヶ原の戦いで三河武士が背を向けず死んで行ったという俗説をはじめ、吉信、鳥居元忠らの盲目的ともいえる三河武士たちの忠節ぶりは敵から『犬のように忠実』と言われた（『葉隠覚書』）。
sen.e: There was a popular view that Samurai in Mikawa was killed without showing their backs to the enemies in the Battle of Mikatagahara, and furthermore, it is also recorded (in" Hagakure-oboegaki" (a memorandum on Bushido)) that the blind faithfulness of samurai in Mikawa, including Yoshinobu and Mototada TORII, was called by the enemies "dog-like faithfulness."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: これらのから、少なくとも地元である三河武士が持つ家康への人望は非常に厚かったようである。
sen.e: Therefore, it seems that Ieyasu was very popular and was strongly trusted by samurai at least in the Mikawa area, his base place.

sen.j: しかしながら、これは松平家全体にもいえることでありまた一揆を起こされたことも考慮する必要がある。
sen.e: However, this can be said for the entire Matsudaira family, and it must also be taken into account that an uprising was caused for him

sen.j: 無論、有能な人材も重視し、安祥・岡崎譜代だけでなく今川氏・武田氏・北条氏の旧臣を多く召抱えた。
sen.e: Needless to say, he valued competent persons highly, and employed many former retainers of the Imagawa clan, of the Takeda clan, and of the Hojo clan in addition to those of Fudai retainers in the Ansho and Okazaki areas.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処譜代大名譜代大名の一覧だけでなく： ウェッブ上の表現 ”安祥・岡崎譜代だけでなく” に置き換えた上で訳してあります。

sen.j: 大御所時代には武士のみならず僧・商人・学者、更には英国人・ウィリアム・アダムス（武士として知行を与えたのは家康のみ）と実力も考慮して登用し、江戸幕府の基礎を作り上げていった。
sen.e: In his Ogosho era, he employed, based on competence, priests, merchants and scholars in addition to samurai, and furthermore, William Adams, an Englishman (it was only Ieyasu who gave a foreigner a territory as a samurai), to establish the base of the Edo bakufu.

sen.j: 戦国時代最大の武装宗教勢力であった浄土真宗本願寺は第十一世門主・顕如の死後、顕如の長男・教如と三男・准如が対立した。
sen.e: In Hongan-ji Temple of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism), which was the largest armed religious power in the Sengoku period, Kyonyo, the eldest son of Kennyo, the eleventh chief priest of the temple, and Junnyo, the third son of him confronted.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

In Hongan-ji Temple of Jodo Shinshu sect (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism), which was the largest armed religious power in the Sengoku period, Kyonyo, the eldest son of Kennyo, the eleventh chief priest of the temple, and Junnyo, the third son of him confronted after Kennyo died.
sen.cmt: 用語統一しました。訳漏れ補足しました。

sen.j: 教如が独立する形で東本願寺（真宗大谷派）を設立、後にこれに対して准如が西本願寺（浄土真宗本願寺派）を設立し、東西本願寺に分裂した。
sen.e: Then Kyonyo became independent of the temple and established Higashi (eastern)-Hongan-ji Temple (the Otani group of the Shinshu sect), and for this, Junnyo established Nishi (western)-Hongan-ji Temple (the Hongan-ji group of the Jodo Shinshu sect), separating Hongan-ji Temple into Higashi-Hongan-ji Temple and Nishi-Hongan-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Then Kyonyo became independent of the temple and established Higashi (eastern)-Hongan-ji Temple (the Otani group of the Shinshu sect), and for this, Junnyo established Nishi (western)-Hongan-ji Temple (the Hongan-ji group of the Jodo Shinshu sect), separating Hongan-ji Temple into Higashi-Hongan-ji Temple and Nishi-Hongan-ji Temple.

Then Kyonyo became independent of the temple and established Higashi (eastern)-Hongan-ji Temple (the Otani group of the Shinshu sect), and for this, Junnyo established Nishi (western)-Hongan-ji Temple (the Hongan-ji group of the Jodo Shinshu sect), separating Hongan-ji Temple into Higashi-Hongan-ji Temple and Nishi-Hongan-ji Temple.

sen.j: この分裂劇に関与しているのも家康である。
sen.e: It is said that Ieyasu was also involved in this incident of separating the temple into two.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is said that Ieyasu was also involved in this incident of separating the temple into two.
It is said that Ieyasu was also involved in this incident of separating the temple into two.

sen.j: 定説として、若き日に三河一向一揆に苦しめられた事のある家康が、本願寺の勢力を弱体化させるために、教如をそそのかして本願寺を分裂させたとされてきた。
sen.e: According to an established theory, it is said that Ieyasu, who had suffered from an uprising of Ikko sect followers in Mikawa in his youth, enticed Kyonyo to separate Hongan-ji Temple to make the power of Hongan-ji Temple diminish.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: According to an established theory, it is said that Ieyasu, who had suffered from an uprising of Ikko sect followers in Mikawa in his youth, enticed Kyonyo to separate Hongan-ji Temple to make the power of Hongan-ji Temple diminish.

According to an established theory, it is said that Ieyasu, who had suffered from an uprising of Ikko sect followers in Mikawa in his youth, enticed Kyonyo to separate Hongan-ji Temple to make the power of Hongan-ji Temple diminish.

sen.j: しかしながら、近年になって真宗大谷派が「教如は家康にそそのかされて東本願寺を設立したのではなく、元々独立志向があった」とする見解を史学研究の結果として正式に表明している。
sen.e: However, recently, the Otani group of the Shinshu sect has officially expressed, as a result of history study, the viewpoint that "Kyonyo did not establish Higashi-Hongan-ji Temple by being enticed by Ieyasu but had originally the intention of independence.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

However, recently, the Otani group of the Shinshu sect has officially expressed, as a result of historical study, the viewpoint that Kyonyo did not establish Higashi-Hongan-ji Temple by being enticed by Ieyasu but had originally the intention of independence.

sen.j: そのため、本願寺の東西分裂が通説のような家康の策謀によるものであったか否かは断定できない。
sen.e: Therefore, it is impossible to assert the popular theory that Ieyasu plotted the separation of Hongan-ji Temple into Higashi-Hongan-ji Temple and Nishi-Hongan-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, it is impossible to assert the popular theory that Ieyasu plotted the separation of Hongan-ji Temple into Higashi-Hongan-ji Temple and Nishi-Hongan-ji Temple.
Therefore, it is impossible to assert the popular theory that Ieyasu plotted the separation of Hongan-ji Temple into Higashi-Hongan-ji Temple and Nishi-Hongan-ji Temple.

sen.j: しかし、少なくともこの分裂劇に際し、教如を支持して東本願寺の土地を寄進したのが家康であることは確かである（真宗大谷派も教如の東本願寺の設立に家康の関与があったことは認めている）。
sen.e: However, it leaves no doubt that at least, Ieyasu contributed the land space for building Higashi-Hongan-ji Temple in this incident of separating the temple (even the Otani group of the Shinshu sect admits that Ieyasu was involved in establishing Higashi-Hongan-ji Temple).

However, it leaves no doubt that at least, Ieyasu contributed the land space for building Higashi-Hongan-ji Temple in this incident of separating the temple (even the Otani group of the Shinshu sect admits that Ieyasu was involved in establishing Higashi-Hongan-ji Temple).

However, it leaves no doubt that at least, Ieyasu supported Kyonyo and contributed the land space for building Higashi-Hongan-ji Temple in this incident of separating the temple (even the Otani group of the Shinshu sect admits that Ieyasu was involved in establishing Higashi-Hongan-ji Temple by Kyonyo).

sen.j: そしてこの本願寺の東西分裂によって東西本願寺はお互いに対立関係に陥り、結果戦国時代に諸大名を脅かしたような強大な武装宗教勢力としての形を変えていった。
sen.e: Then after the separation of Hongan-ji Temple, Higashi-Hongan-ji Temple and Nishii-Hongan-ji Temple became to confront each other, and resultantly, the sect gradually lost the strong armed religious power that had been threatened daimyo in the Sengoku period.

Then after the separation of Hongan-ji Temple, Higashi-Hongan-ji Temple and Nishii-Hongan-ji Temple came to confront each other, and resultantly, the sect gradually lost the strong armed religious power that had been threatened daimyo in the Sengoku period.

Then after the separation of Hongan-ji Temple, Higashi-Hongan-ji Temple and Nishii-Hongan-ji Temple came to confront each other, and resultantly, the sect gradually lost the strong armed religious power that had been threatened daimyo in the Sengoku period.

sen.j: かつて、信長は本願寺と交戦しその後和睦したが、実質的には長年猛威を振るってきた本願寺の権威を失墜させるなどの弱体化に成功した。
sen.e: Once, Nobunaga fought with the forces of Hongan-ji Temple and then made peace with them, but succeeded in undermining the power of Hongan-ji Temple, for example, by virtually making lose the authority of the temple that had exerted an overwhelming influence for long years.

sen.j: 秀吉は逆にこれを懐柔しようとした。
sen.e: On the contrary, Hideyoshi tried to placate the temple forces.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: しかしながら、家康の場合はその関与の度合いは不明とは言え、結果的に本願寺を内部分裂させ、彼らの自滅を誘う形でその勢力を更に弱めていった。
sen.e: However, although to what extent Ieyasu was involved in the affairs of the temple, he resultantly made Hongan-ji Temple separated internally, making weaker the power of the temple in the form of inducing the self-destruction.

sen.j: この事も家康の老獪さを表す事象として捉えられることがある。
sen.e: This can also be counted as an example showing his cunningness.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This can also be counted as an example showing his cunning.

sen.j: ただし、三河一向一揆が起こった際、敵方の一向宗側には本多正信や夏目吉信など、家康の家来だった者もいた。
sen.e: However, when the uprising of Ikko sect followers in Mikawa occurred, the enemy Ikko sect side included Ieyasu's former retainers, such as Masanobu HONDA and Yoshinobu NATSUME.
However, when the uprising of Ikko sect followers in Mikawa occurred, the enemy Ikko sect side included Ieyasu's former retainers, such as Masanobu HONDA and Yoshinobu NATSUME.

sen.j: だが家康は彼らを怨まず、逆に再び召抱えている。
sen.e: However, Ieyasu did not resent them but employed them again.
However, Ieyasu did not resent them but employed them again.
However, Ieyasu did not resent them but employed them again.

sen.j: 彼らは家康に恩を感じ、本多正信は家康の晩年までブレーンとして活躍し、夏目吉信は三方ヶ原の戦いで家康の身代わりになって戦死した。
sen.e: Therefore, they had a feeling of an obligation to Ieyasu: For example, Masanobu HONDA was one of Ieyasu's brains until Ieyasu's later years, and Yoshinobu NATSUME was killed in place of Ieyasu in the Battle of Mikatagahara.

Therefore, they had a feeling of obligation to Ieyasu: For example, Masanobu HONDA was one of Ieyasu's brains until Ieyasu's later years, and Yoshinobu NATSUME was killed in place of Ieyasu in the Battle of Mikatagahara.

Therefore, they had a feeling of obligation to Ieyasu: For example, Masanobu HONDA was one of Ieyasu's brains until Ieyasu's later years, and Yoshinobu NATSUME was killed in place of Ieyasu in the Battle of Mikatagahara.

sen.j: また、同様に町衆に対し強い影響力を有する日蓮宗に対しても、秀吉が命じた方広寺大仏殿の千僧供養時に他宗の布施を受ける事を容認した日蓮宗受布施派と、禁じた宗義に従った日蓮宗不受不施派の内、後者を家康は公儀に従わぬ者として日蓮宗が他宗への攻撃色が強い事も合わせて危険視した。
sen.e: Furthermore, similarly, Ieyasu thought that the Nichiren sect, which had strong influence over townspeople, was dangerous for the following reasons: In holding Senso-kuyo (a religious ritual where 1,000 priest were invited) at the Daibutsu-den hall of Hoko-ji Temple, ordered by Hideyoshi, the Nichiren-sect was divided into the Jufuseha group, which admitted receiving offerings from other religious sects, and Fu-jufuseha group led by Sogi, which did not admit receiving offerings from other religious sects; In this situation, Ieyasu decided that the latter group did not follow orders of the bakufu and had also the feeling that the Nichiren set was rather aggressive to other religious sects.

Furthermore, similarly, Ieyasu thought that the Nichiren sect, which had strong influence over townspeople, was dangerous for the following reasons: In holding Senso-kuyo (a religious ritual where 1,000 priest were invited) at the Daibutsu-den hall of Hoko-ji Temple, ordered by Hideyoshi, the Nichiren-sect was divided into the Jufuseha group, which admitted receiving offerings from other religious sects, and Fu-jufuseha group led by Sogi, which did not admit receiving offerings from other religious sects; In this situation, Ieyasu decided that the latter group did not follow orders of the bakufu and had also the feeling that the Nichiren set was rather aggressive to other religious sects.

sen.j: その為、後の家康の出仕命令に従わぬ不受不施派の日奥を対馬国に配流したり、他宗への攻撃が激しい日経らを耳・鼻削ぎの上で追放した。
sen.e: Therefore, Ieyasu exiled to Tsushima Province Nichio, a member of the Fu-jufuseha group, who did not follow Ieyasu's order for serving the bakufu later, and Nikkyo and others who were aggressive in criticizing other religious sects had their ears and noses chipped off and were exiled.

Therefore, Ieyasu exiled to Tsushima Province Nichio, a member of the Fu-jufuseha group, who did not follow Ieyasu's order for serving the bakufu later, and Nikkyo and others who were aggressive in criticizing other religious sects had their ears and noses chipped off and were exiled.

Therefore, Ieyasu exiled to Tsushima Province Nichio, a member of the Fu-jufuseha group, who did not follow Ieyasu's order for serving the bakufu later, and Nikkyo and others who were aggressive in criticizing other religious sects had their ears and noses chipped off and were exiled.

sen.j: 家康死後も不受不施派は江戸幕府の布施供養を受けぬ事を理由として、江戸時代を通じて弾圧され続けた。
sen.e: Even after Ieyasu's death, the Fu-jufuseha group continued being repressed for the reason that the group did not accept religious offerings from the Edo bakufu.
Even after Ieyasu's death, the Fu-jufuseha group continued to be repressed for the reason that the group did not accept religious offerings from the Edo bakufu.
Even after Ieyasu's death, the Fu-jufuseha group continued to be repressed for the reason that the group did not accept religious offerings from the Edo bakufu.

sen.j: これら新興の宗教以外の古い天台宗・真言宗・法相宗にも独占した門跡を通じ朝廷との深い繋がりを懸念し、新たに浄土宗知恩院を門跡に加え、更に天台宗・真言宗の頂点として輪王寺に門跡を設けて天台座主の座を独占した。
sen.e: In addition to these newly-emerging religious sects, Ieyasu also cared about the older Tendai sect, Shingon sect, and Hosso sect concerning their connections with the Imperial court through the Monzeki posts (the head priest posts of these temples), and he newly added the Monzeki post to Chion-in Temple of the Jodo sect and furthermore, to Rinno-ji Temple as the pinnacle temple of the Tendai sect and of the Shinshu sect, monopolizing the head priest posts of the Tendai sect.

In addition to these newly-emerging religious sects, Ieyasu also cared about the older Tendai sect, Shingon sect, and Hosso sect concerning their connections with the Imperial court through the Monzeki posts (the head priest posts of these temples), and he newly added the Monzeki post to Chion-in Temple of the Jodo sect and furthermore, to Rinno-ji Temple as the pinnacle temple of the Tendai sect and of the Shinshu sect, monopolizing the head priest posts of the Tendai sect.

sen.j: これら知恩院・輪王寺は江戸幕府と強い繋がりを持ち、後の幕府による寺請制度等により幕府は宗教を完全に公儀の下に置くことに成功している。
sen.e: Chion-in Temple and Rinno-ji Temple had a strong connection with the Edo bakufu, and with the Terauke seido (the system in which the public should be registered in one of designated temples to prove their Buddhist faith) established,the bakufu succeeded in placing religion completely under it.

sen.j: 明治維新後に家康の悪評が高まったのは、明治政府が江戸幕府を倒して建てられた政権であり、江戸時代を悪とするのが明治政府にとって都合が良いことであったからと言える。
sen.e: It can be said that Ieyasu became to be evaluated badly in the Meiji Restoration and later, because it was convenient for the Meiji government, which was established after it defeated the Edo bakufu, to make bad what was in the Edo period.

sen.j: 特に太平洋戦争前は、秀吉の朝鮮出兵（文禄・慶長の役）が大日本帝国における、帝国主義的な領土拡大と合致し、「朝鮮征伐」と称されるほど是とされていた。
sen.e: In particular, before the Pacific War, the dispatch of troops to Korea by Hideyoshi (the Bunroku-Keicho War) was considered right to the extent that it was called "the subjugation of Korea," because it met the trend of imperialistic territory expansion in Empire of Japan at that time.

sen.j: そのため、「秀吉は清君、それに背いた家康は奸君」と偏った評価をされることが多かった。
sen.e: Therefore, the biased evaluation of "Hideyoshi was a clean ruler, while Ieyasu was a cunning ruler" was often made.

sen.j: この時期は家康らの尊敬の対象であった平将門や足利尊氏に対しても朝廷に刃向かった逆賊として批判的な評価がなされていた時期である（足利尊氏に対しては家康も批判的だったとする説もある）。
sen.e: In this era, critical evaluations were also made for TAIRA no Masakado and Takauji ASHIKAGA, who were respected by Ieyasu and others, as rebels who had defied the imperial court (there is a theory as well that Ieyasu was also critical of Takauji ASHIKAGA).

sen.j: 山岡荘八の小説『徳川家康』では、幼い頃から我慢に我慢を重ねて、逆境や困難にも決して屈することもなく先見の明をもって勝利を勝ち取った人物、平和を求める理想主義者として描かれている。
sen.e: In "Ieyasu TOKUGAWA," a novel by Sohachi YAMAOKA, Ieyasu was depicted as a person who restrained himself again and again from his early age, endured adversity and difficulties, and wan victories with foresight, or as a realist seeking peace.

sen.j: この小説によって家康への再評価が始まり、それは現在も続いている。
sen.e: With this novel, the re-evaluation of Ieyasu started and still continues.

sen.j: そのため、家康を苦労人・不屈の精神力の持ち主として高く評する者もある。
sen.e: Therefore, there are also people who evaluate Ieyasu highly as a man who saw the world and had indomitable spirit.

sen.j: 一方、司馬遼太郎は家康について記した小説「覇王の家」あとがきで、家康が築いた江戸時代については「功罪半ばする」とし、「（日本人の）民族的性格が矮小化され、奇形化された」といった論やその支配の閉鎖ないし保守性については極めて批判的である。
sen.e: On the other hand, in the postscript of "Hasha no Ie," a novel about Ieyasu, Ryotaro SHIBA wrote that "There were bad aspects as well as good aspects" in the Edo period started by Ieyasu, and he also pointed out that "The ethnic natures of the Japanese were made undersized and deformed," and he was quite critical about the closed nature and conservatism of the control.

On the other hand, in the postscript of "Hasha no Ie," a novel about Ieyasu, Ryotaro SHIBA wrote that "There were bad aspects as well as good aspects" in the Edo period started by Ieyasu, and he also pointed out that "The ethnic natures of the Japanese were made undersized and deformed," and he was quite critical about the closed nature and conservatism of the control.

sen.j: 天下を平定したとはいえ、信長・秀吉に比べて守旧的な組織しか作らなかったとして、家康を名君・奸君とするのは過大評価であるとする説もある。
sen.e: There is also the theory that it is an overvaluation to consider Ieyasu an excellent ruler or cunning ruler, because, although he unified the nation, he established only conservative systems, compared with Nobunaga and Hideyoshi.

There is also the theory that it is an overestimation to consider Ieyasu an excellent ruler or cunning ruler, because, although he unified the nation, he established only conservative systems, compared with Nobunaga and Hideyoshi.

sen.j: 家康は、独断で物事を決するよりは、専ら評定を開いては家臣だけで議論をさせ、家臣たちが結論を出したところで決断をするところから、あくまでその議論のまとめ役や政策実行の代表者に過ぎない（部下の使い方がうまいという見方もある）、たまたま長生きしたために天下を取ることができた凡人に過ぎないとする意見もある。
sen.e: There exists the following opinion as well: Rather than determining things independently, Ieyasu held meetings and made his retainers discuss them, and made decisions after they reached conclusions, and therefore, he was only an organizer of discussions or the representative of policy-executing staffs (there is also a viewpoint that he was good at using subordinates), and he could unify the nation because he happened to live a long life and actually was only an ordinary person.

sen.j: 武光誠の『凡将家康天下取りの謎』がこの説を採っており、池宮彰一郎の小説『遁げろ家康』もこの観点より書かれている。
sen.e: "Bonsho-Ieyasu-tenkatorino-nazo" (The riddles why Ieyasu, an ordinary military commander, could unify the nation) written by Makoto TAKEMITSU employs this theory, and "Nigero Ieyasu" (Escape! Ieyasu), a novel by Shoichiro IKEMIYA, is written form this viewpoint as well.

sen.j: 家康公遺訓
sen.e: Lord Ieyasu's teachings
Lord Ieyasu's teachings
Lord Ieyasu's teachings

sen.j: 「人の一生は重荷を負ふて遠き道をゆくがごとし… 怒りは敵とおもへ」で有名な家康公の「御遺訓」は、明治時代に元500石取りの幕臣、池田松之介が徳川光圀の遺訓と言われる「人のいましめ」を元に家康63歳の自筆花押文書との体裁にしたものを高橋泥舟らが日光東照宮など各地の東照宮に収めたものであることを尾張徳川家の徳川義宣が考証した。
sen.e: Based on historical evidence, Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA of the Owari-Tokugawa family made clear that Lord Ieyasu's "Goikun" (teachings), which includes the famous phrase of "A person's life is as if going on a long road with a heavy burden on its back --- Consider that anger is an enemy," had the following origin: First, in the Meiji period, Matsunosuke IKEDA, a shogun's former retainer having earned a 500 koku of rice crop, made documents with an autograph sign of 63-year-old Ieyasu, based on "Hitono-imashime" (Admonitions), which had been said being TOKUGAWA's teachings, and then Deishu TAKAHASHI and others dedicated them to Tosho-gu shrines in various areas, including Nikko Tosho-gu Shrine.

sen.e: "Tosho-gu Goikun" (Goikun at Tosho-gu Shrine) (or "Ieyasu-ko Goikun" (Goikun by Lord Ieyasu)), whose contents are very similar to those of the above document, is also called "Matsunaga Dosai Kikigaki" (verbatim accounts of what Dosai MATSUNAGA heard), "Inoue Kazu no kami Kikigaki" (verbatim accounts of what Inoue Kazu no kami heard) or "Banzaishi."

sen.j: これは松永道斎が、井上主計頭（井上正就）が元和 (日本)の初め、二代将軍徳川秀忠の使いで駿府の家康のもとに数日間の滞在した際に家康から聞いた話を収録したものという。
sen.e: It is said that what Dosai MATSUNAGA and Inoue Kazue no kami (Masanari INOUE), sent to Ieyasu at Sunpu by Hidetada Tokugawa, the second shogun, in the early Genna era (1615 - 1624), heard from Ieyasu during their several-days' stay there, were recorded in it.

sen.j: 家康は現在でいう健康おたくであり、当時としては極めて長寿の75歳（満73歳4ヵ月）まで生きた。
sen.e: Ieyasu was extremely enthusiastic about heath, and lived an extraordinary long life for the standard at that time (for 75 years when his life was counted in the number of years where he lived) (or for 73 years and four months in the actual life length).

sen.j: 元々凝り性だった家康は食事のつりあい、消化のよさなどを考えて台所に献立を通達していたと言われている。
sen.e: It is said that being finicky originally, Ieyasu considered the balance of foods to eat as well as digestion and notified the kitchen of the information.

sen.j: その食事は質素で、戦国武将として戦場にいた頃の食生活を崩さなかった。
sen.e: His meals were austere, and he maintained the eating habit in the fighting field as a military commander in the Sengoku period.
His meals were austere, and he maintained the eating habit in the fighting field as a military commander in the Sengoku period.

sen.j: 死因となったともいわれた鯛の天ぷらは、生涯の最初で最後の贅沢であった（さらに言えば、鯛の天ぷらは当時の常識で言えば漁師などが食べるものであり、必ずしも贅沢すぎるものではなかった）。
sen.e: The fried sea bream that might have caused his death was his first and last extravagance in hi life (adding more, fried sea breams were eaten by fishermen, and according to the common sense at that time, they were not too extravagant).

sen.j: また生薬にも精通し、その知識は専門家が舌を巻くほどのもので一説には自分で調合していたとも、孫の家光の大病を治したとも言われるほどである。
sen.e: He was familiar with natural drugs and had so profound knowledge that astonished even drug specialists, and according to a theory, it is also said that he mixed drug materials by himself and that he cured a disease of Iemitsu, his grandson.

He was familiar with natural drugs and had such profound knowledge that astonished even drug specialists, and according to a theory, it is also said that he mixed drug materials by himself and that he cured a disease of Iemitsu, his grandson.

He was familiar with natural drugs and had such profound knowledge that astonished even drug specialists, and according to a theory, it is also said that he mixed drug materials by himself and that he cured a disease of Iemitsu, his grandson.

sen.j: 逆にしばしば水銀など劇薬まがいの薬剤を利用して強過ぎる薬を調合し、常備薬のように服用したため、専門家から諌言されていたとも言われる（なお、当時水銀は梅毒の治療薬に用いられていたため、家康が梅毒であったと推測できる）。
sen.e: On the other hand, it is also said that he often produced too strong drugs by using drug materials near to powerful medicines like mercury and took them like household medicines, and therefore, he was admonished by drug specialists (by the way, mercury was used as a drug for treating syphilis, and it is surmised that he suffered from syphilis).

sen.j: ちなみに、精力剤である海狗腎は家康の薬の調合に使用されたという記録が残っている。
sen.e: By the way, it is recorded that Hai Gou Shen (male seal sexual organs), an aphrodisiac, was used in drugs for Ieyasu.

sen.j: 関ヶ原合戦では、家来に石鹸を使用させ、感染症を予防させている。
sen.e: In the Battle of Sekigahara, he made his retainers use soap fro protection against infectious diseases

sen.j: また趣味の一つとされる鷹狩りに関して、司馬遼太郎は「運動が健康にいい事を知った日本で初めての人物かも知れない」と『覇王の家』の中で述べている。
sen.e: Concerning falconry, one of his hobbies, Ryotaro SHIBA wrote in "Hasha no Ie" that "He might have been the first person in Japan who had the knowledge that physical exercise is good for health."

sen.j: 裏がつるつるで滑りやすかった南蛮渡来のくつの裏に日本のわらじからヒントを得て滑り止めの溝を彫らせ滑りにくくしたという挿話もある。
sen.e: There is the following anecdote: The shoes from Europe were slippery with a smooth sole, and for this, getting a hint from straw sandals in Japan, he made the sole grooved to make it not slippery.

sen.j: 武術の達人
sen.e: He was a master in martial art
He was a master in martial arts
He was a master in martial arts

sen.j: 剣術、砲術、弓術、馬術、日本泳法等の日本武術について一流の域に達していた。
sen.e: He was an expert in the Japanese martial art of swordplay, gunnery, archery, equestrian art, and Japanese swimming art.
He was an expert in the Japanese martial arts of swordplay, gunnery, archery, equestrian art, and Japanese swimming.

sen.j: 剣術は、新当流の有馬満盛、上泉信綱の新陰流の流れをくむ神影流（『奥平家譜』、直心影流伝書による、 なお『急賀斎由緒書』では奥山流）
sen.e: His swordplay was that of the Shinkage-ryu (新陰流) school that originated in the Shinto-ryu school by Mitsumori ARIMA and in the Shinkage-ryu (神影流) school by Nobutsuna KAMIIZUMI (according to "Okudaira-ke Fu" (a family tree of the Okudaira family) and a document on the Jikishinkage-ryu school swordplay that has been handed down for generations; However his swordplay was that of the Okuyama-ryu school according to "Kyugasai Yuishogaki" (a kind of family tree of Kyugasai)).
sen.cmt: 奥平家譜： 正しい読み、訳とも不明です。次行冒頭部をこちらに移した上で訳してあります。

sen.cmt: 漢字の位置を入れ替えました。

sen.j: 剣術開祖で家来でもある奥平久賀（号の一に急賀斎）に姉川の戦いから7年間師事、文禄2年（1593年）に小野忠明を200石（一刀流剣術の伊東一刀斎の推薦）で秀忠の指南として、文禄3年（1594年）に新陰流の柳生宗矩（柳生宗厳と立ち会って無刀取りされたため宗厳に剣術指南役として出仕を命ずるも、宗厳は老齢を理由に辞退）を召抱える、など、生涯かけて学んでいた。
sen.e: He learned his swordplay in the following way throughout his life: He learnt it from Kyuga OKUDAIRA (Kyugasai was one of his names as a swordsman), a founder of swordplay as well as his retainer, for seven years from the Battle of Anegawa, employed Tadaaki ONO (recommended by Ittosai ITO in the Itto-ryu school of swordplay) as the swordplay instructor for Hidetada at a stipend of a 500 koku of rice crop a year, and also employed Munenori YAGYU (Ieyasu fought with Muneyoshi YAGYU in a swordplay match and was defeated with Munenori using no sword, and therefore, ordered Muneyoshi to serve the bakufu as a swordplay instructor, but he declined the order because of his advanced age.

sen.cmt: 数字修正しました。年号補足しました。記号を修正しました。

sen.j: ただし、家康本人は「家臣が周囲にいる貴人には、最初の一撃から身を守る剣法は必要だが、相手を切る剣術は不要である」と発言したと『三河物語』にあり、息子にも「大将は戦場で直接闘うものではない」と言っていたといわれる。
sen.e: However, it is recorded in "Mikawa Monogatari" (Tales in Mikawa) that Ieyasu himself said "For a noble man around whom his retainers exist, the swordplay to protect himself from an initial attack is necessary, but the swordplay to kill his opponent is unnecessary," and it is also said that he told his sons that taisho (generals) should not directly fight in the fighting field."

However, it is recorded in "Mikawa Monogatari" (Tales in Mikawa) that Ieyasu himself said "For a noble man around whom his retainers exist, the swordplay to protect himself from an initial attack is necessary, but the swordplay to kill his opponent is unnecessary," and it is also said that he told his sons that taisho (generals) should not directly fight in the fighting field."

sen.j: 水術についても、69歳の時、駿河の川で見事な泳ぎぶりを家臣に披露している。
sen.e: Concerning swimming art, he showed in a river in the Suruga area how excellently he could swim, when he was 69 years old.

sen.j: 馬術も、室町時代初期の大坪慶秀を祖とする大坪流馬術を学んでいる。
sen.e: Concerning equestrian art, he learnt the Otsubo school of the art that originated in Keisho OTSUBO in the early Muromachi period.

sen.j: また、力も強く、70歳の時に総長4尺7寸（1.4m）の火縄銃で鳶を撃ち落としている。
sen.e: With a strong physical power as well, he shot down a kite with 1.4-m matchlock gun at the age of 70.

sen.j: 多趣味
sen.e: He had many hobbies.
He had many hobbies.

sen.j: 歴史小説等で鷹狩りと薬づくり以外無趣味とされることが多い家康であるが、実はそれ以外にもたくさん趣味があった。
sen.e: In historical stories and others, Ieyasu was often depicted as a man who had no hobby other than falconry and making drugs, but actually he had many other hobbies.

sen.j: 猿楽（現在の名称は能）は、若い頃から世阿弥の家系に連なる観世十郎太夫に学び、自ら演じるだけでなく、「風姿花伝」で学び故実にも通じていた。
sen.e: He learnt Sarugaku (called Noh at present) from Kanze Juro-tayu, who was in the family line of Zeami, from his earlier years, and not only played it but learnt through "Fushikaden," and therefore, he was familiar with old customs and manners as well.

sen.j: なお、家康は武士的な気概や人情味のある猿楽が好きであったが家臣が茶の湯（現茶道）等に凝るのを好まなかった。
sen.e: Ieyasu was fond of Sarugaku where samurai spirit and human touches were shown, but did not like his retainers to become devoted to chanoyu (present tea ceremony)

sen.j: また、香（特に香木）を好み、海外まで使いを出している。
sen.e: He was fond of incense (fragrant woods, in particular), and sent persons overseas to get such woods.

sen.j: 囲碁も本因坊算砂に師事、特に浅野長政とはよい碁敵だった。
sen.e: He learnt Igo (board game of capturing territories) from Sansa HONINBO, and Nagamasa ASANO was his good rival in Igo

sen.j: 自身で嗜んだのみならず家元を保護し、確立した功績から、彼は囲碁殿堂として顕彰されている。
sen.e: Because not only he himself played Igo but also protected the head family of the Igo school and established the Igo society, he was praised publicly in the hall of fame for Igo.

sen.j: 当時武士の間では普通だった衆道にはあまり興味がなかったが、後に徳川四天王に数えられる小姓井伊万千代（井伊直政）は衆道に無関心だった家康が唯一愛した男性であるといわれる。
sen.e: He had not much interest in male homosexuality that was not unusual among samurai at that time, but it is said that Manchiyo II (later Naomasa II), a pageboy who became to be counted later as one of Tokugawa-shitenno (the four powerful generals serving Tokugawa Ieyasu), was only one male that Ieyasu loved.

sen.j: 武田信玄に大いに苦しめられた家康ではあるが、施政には軍事・政治共に武田家を手本にしたものが多い。
sen.e: Although having been greatly tormented by Shingen TAKEDA, Ieyasu followed his examples on many policies he took, both in military and political affairs.

sen.j: 天正10年（1582年）に武田家を滅亡させた後、織田信長に武田残党狩りを命じられた際も、信長の命令を無視し武田の遺臣をかくまった。
sen.e: When ordered to kill remaining retainers of the Takeda clan by Nobunaga ODA after he ruined the Takeda family in 1582, Ieyasu ignored Nobunaga's order to shelter them..

sen.j: 自分の五男・信吉に「武田」の苗字を与え、武田信吉と名乗らせ水戸藩を治めさせている。
sen.e: He gave the family name of "Takeda" to his fifth son, Nobuyoshi, and made him govern Mito Domain with the name of Nobuyoshi TAKEDA.

sen.j: 有名な井伊直政の赤備えも、武田の猛将山県昌景にあやかったものである。
sen.e: Famous red-colored arms of Naosuke II also followed the example of Masakage YAMAGATA, a brave general of the Takeda clan.

sen.j: それとは反し、幼馴染であり盟友であった織田信長に対しては反応が鈍く、政策に信長を手本にしたようなものは少ない。
sen.e: On the contrary, he was slow to respond to Nobunaga ODA, his friend from his childhood and his sworn ally, and he scarcely followed Nobunaga's policies.

sen.e: In his later years, Ieyasu was fond of talking about old times, including the Imagawa era when he lived a life like a prisoner, but it is said that he did not talk about his impressions of Nobunaga (according to a theory, it is said that he resented Nobunaga).

sen.e: It is said to be auspicious that one dreams Fuji Mountain, a hawk or an eggplant in the first night of the year, but according to a theory, it is also said that these three items were a list of what Ieyasu liked.

sen.j: 好学の士
sen.e: He liked learning.

sen.j: 家康の愛読書は、『論語』、『中庸』、『史記』、『漢書』、『六韜』、『三略』、『貞観政要』、『延喜式』、『吾妻鑑』などの書物だと伝えられている。
sen.e: It is said that he liked reading "Rongo" (Analects of Confucius), "Chuyo" (Doctrine of the Mean), "Shiki" (the Chinese Historical Records), "Kanjo" (historical records of the Han Dynasty), "Rikuto" (an ancient Chinese strategy book), "Sanryaku" (an ancient Chinese strategy book), "Joganseiyo" (a book written about Taiso, the second Emperor of Tang Dynasty in China), "Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), and "Azuma kagami."

sen.j: 家康はこれらの書物を関ヶ原以前より木版印刷（伏見版）で、大御所になってからは銅活字版（駿府版）で印刷・刊行していた。

sen.e: It is said that Ieyasu had a masukake line (his teso was stored in the treasure hall in Nikkosan-Rinno-ji Temple in Tochigi Prefecture).

sen.j: 因みにマスカケ線の持ち主は、国家を支配する強運の持ち主が多く、現代でもあらゆる分野のトップ達に多く見られる。
sen.e: By the way, many of the persons with a masukara line had the good luck of ruling a nation, and even today, many persons in top groups of various fields had this teso.

sen.j: 「徳川の宝はなにか？」との秀吉の問いに対し、「五百騎の三河武士である」と返答している。
sen.e: For the question of "What is the treasure of Tokugawa?" made by Hideyoshi, he replied that "it was 500 samurai in Mikawa."

sen.j: 悪筆？
sen.e: He was not good at handwriting?

sen.j: 『永茗夜話』には渡辺幸庵の話として「権現様（家康）は無筆同様の悪筆にて候」とある。
sen.e: In "Eimeiyawa," the following description is included as what Koan WATANABE talked: "The handwriting of Gongen-sama (Ieyasu) is as bad as that of persons who had no knowledge of writing."

sen.j: ただし、直筆文章とされる書状などを見ると読めないような悪筆ではないため、当時流行の筆捌きでないと言う意味かもしれない。
sen.e: However, the handwriting of the letters considered having been written by Ieyasu himself is not so bad that they cannot be read., and therefore, it is considered that Watanabe might have meant that Ieyasu's handwriting style was not the one that was popular at that time.

sen.j: 吝嗇
sen.e: He was stingy.

sen.j: 家康のけちにまつわる逸話は多い。
sen.e: There are many anecdotes related to Ieyasu's stinginess.

sen.j: 手洗いから出て懐紙で手を拭こうとしたら、懐紙が風に飛ばされたので庭まで追っていって取り返した（それを見て笑う家来に対し、「わしはこれで天下を取ったのだ」と言い返している）。
sen.e: When he tried to dry his hands with Kaishi (Japanese tissue) after coming out of a lavatory, the Kaishi flied with wind, and he chased after it to the garden to take it back (for the retainers who laughed seeing the scene, he retorted that "I have become the ruler of the nation in this way."

When he tried to dry his hands with Kaishi (Japanese tissue) after coming out of a lavatory, the Kaishi flew away with the wind, and he chased after it to the garden to take it back (for the retainers who laughed seeing the scene, he retorted that "I have become the ruler of the nation in this way").

sen.j: 新しい服をあまり買わず、洗濯して使っていたため、洗濯させられる侍女から新しい服を着てほしいと苦情が出たとき、天下のため倹約するのだと逆に説教した。
sen.e: His clothes were washed frequently because he rarely bought new clothes, and when the female servant, who had been forced to wash them, complained that she wanted Ieyasu to buy new clothes, he told her in an admonishing tone that he saved money for the nation.

sen.j: また、侍女から料理の漬物がしょっぱいという苦情が出たので料理人に問いただしたところ、今でも侍女たちはたくさんおかわりしているのに、おいしい漬物を出したら何杯おかわりするかわからないと答えられ、笑ってそのままにした。
sen.e: When female servants once complained that pickles of their dishes were salty, he inquired the complaint of the cook, and getting the following answer, he left the matter intact: "Even now, the female servants ask for another helping many times, and it is unconceivable how many more times they will become to ask for another helping when more delicious pickles are served."

sen.j: 侍が座敷で相撲をしている時に畳を裏返すように言った。
sen.e: When samurai were doing Sumo-wrestling on a tatami-mat room, he ordered that the other side of the straw-like cover should be used instead.

sen.j: 駿府の銭鋳所跡地を掘り返して、銅を3年で運上金千両回収した。
sen.e: He made the former coin-minting site in Sunpu dug up, and recovered the amount of copper corresponding to 1,000-ryo (ryo: a monetary unit at that time) business tax.

sen.j: 装飾を施した便器に激怒し、直ちに壊させた。
sen.e: He became quite angry about a decorated toilet, and made it destroyed immediately.

sen.j: 代官からの金銀納入報告を直に聞き、貫目単位までは蔵に収め、残りの匁・分単位を私用分として女房衆を集めて計算させた。
sen.e: He had the collected tax amount of gold and silver reported directly by the daikan (the bakufu officer sent tot the domain), and made the amount up to the units of Kan and Mon (Kan and Mon: each a monetary unit at that time) stored in a warehouse, and made female servants gather to count the remaining amount corresponding to Monme and Bu (Monme and Bu: each a monetary unit at that time) for private use.

sen.j: 三河にいた時、夏に家康は麦飯を食べていた。
sen.e: When residing in Mikawa, he ate boiled barley in summer.

sen.j: ある時部下が米飯の上に麦をのせ出した所、戦国の時代において百姓にばかり苦労させて（夏は最も食料がなくなる時期）自分だけ飽食できるかと言った。
sen.e: When, on an occasion in the Sengoku period, one of his retainers offered boiled rice with boiled barley on top of it, he said that, in such a period, he could not glut himself either, while farmers continued sufferrring (foods became most scanty in summer).

When, on an occasion in the Sengoku period, one of his retainers offered boiled rice with boiled barley on top of it, he said that, in such a period, he could not be a glutton himself while farmers continued suffering (foods became most scanty in summer).

sen.j: 厩が壊れても、そちらのほうが頑強な馬が育つと言い、そのままにした。
sen.e: When a stable was damaged, he said that horses would grow stronger in such a condition and made the stable left as it was

sen.j: 家臣が華美な屋敷を作らないよう与える敷地は小さくし、自身の屋敷も質素であった。
sen.e: He gave his retainers small house-building space so that they would not build pompous residences, and his residence itself was austere as well.

sen.j: 蒲生氏郷は秀吉の後に天下を取れる人物として前田利家をあげ、家康は人に知行を多く与えないので天下人にはなれないといった。
sen.e: Ujisato GAMO cited Toshiie MAEDA as the person who could become the ruler of the nation following Hideyoshi, and said that Ieyasu could not become Tenkabito (the ruler of the nation), because he did not give lots of territories to others.

sen.e: Resultantly, Ieyasu left a vast amount of assets to the next generation.

sen.j: ただし『落穂集追加』では家康のは吝嗇でなく倹約と評している。
sen.e: However, in "Ochiboshu Tsuika" (An addition to Gleanings), Ieyasu was evaluated as not having been mean but thrifty.

sen.j: 家康の生誕地は、三河国・岡崎市だが、生涯を通じて現在の静岡県（浜松・駿府）を本城あるいは生活の拠点としている期間が長かった。
sen.e: Ieyasu was born in Okazaki City, Mikawa Province, but lived in present Shizuoka Prefecture for a long period of time throughout his life, in his main castle there or as the base site of his life.

sen.j: 岡崎市にいたのは、尾張国の織田氏のもとで人質として過ごした2年を含め、幼少期及び桶狭間の戦い後10年と短い。
sen.e: The total length of the period when he lived in Okazaki City was a short time of ten years combining those in his childhood years and those after the Battle of Okehazama, including the periods when he lived as a hostage with the Oda family in Owari Province.

sen.j: 影武者説
sen.e: The theory that he was a shadowy person
The theory that he was a shadowy person
The theory that he was a shadowy person

sen.j: 大坂夏の陣の際に家康は真田信繁に討ち取られ、混乱を避け幕府の安定作業を円滑に進めるために影武者が病死するまで家康の座を代行させていたとされる説。
sen.e: This theory as follows: Ieyasu was killed by Nobushige SANADA in Osaka Natsu no Jin (Summer Siege of Osaka), and a shadowy person acted in place of Ieyasu until he died due to illness, to avoid the confusion that would ensue otherwise and to make the work to stabilize the bakufu progressed smoothly.
